headline: Praxair Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Full Year and Fourth Quarter 2015 Praxair Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference call is being recorded. I would now like to turn the call over to introduce your
componenttext: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Full Year and Fourth Quarter 2015 Praxair Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference call is being recorded. I would now like to turn the call over to introduce your host for today's conference, Ms. Kelcey Hoyt, Director of Investor Relations. Ma'am, you may begin.

headline: Praxair Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Tamara. Good morning, and thank you for attending our Fourth Quarter Earnings Call and Webcast. I'm joined this morning by Matt White, Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. Today's presentation materials are available on our website
componenttext:
Thanks, Tamara. Good morning, and thank you for attending our Fourth Quarter Earnings Call and Webcast. I'm joined this morning by Matt White, Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. 
Today's presentation materials are available on our website at praxair.com in the Investors section. Please read the forward-looking statements disclosure on Page 2 of the slides, and note that it applies to all statements made during this teleconference. 
Please also note that our discussion of earnings, including year-over-year and sequential comparison, excludes previously disclosed adjustments in 2015 and 2014. These items are detailed and reconciled to the reported GAAP numbers in the appendices to this presentation and the press release. 
Matt and I will now review Praxair's 2015 full year and fourth quarter results as well as our outlook for 2016, including earnings guidance. We'll then be available to answer any questions.

headline: Praxair Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Kelcey, and good morning, everyone. I'd like to kick off the call with a recap of 2015 and then update you on the trends we are currently seeing in the business segments. It's pretty clear that there were some tough macro headwinds in 2015. Doub
componenttext:
Thanks, Kelcey, and good morning, everyone. I'd like to kick off the call with a recap of 2015 and then update you on the trends we are currently seeing in the business segments. 
It's pretty clear that there were some tough macro headwinds in 2015. Double-digit foreign currency devaluations, some of the worst recessionary conditions on record in South America and a plummet in commodity prices created challenging conditions for industrial growth. Despite these events, our organization did what it does best, adapt to current conditions and take appropriate actions on things we can't control. And while there were  many accomplishments of our employees around the world to mitigate these challenges, I'd like to highlight 4 key areas. 
First, we continued with our strong management of costs and price. This is a hallmark of the Praxair culture. We adjusted our cost structure in line with economic trends, saving over $75 million per year. We improved pricing levels in nearly every region of the world, and we delivered strong productivity results. All of these efforts were quite visible in the financial statements and led to record operating and EBITDA margins of 23.1% and 33.8%, respectively. 
Second, we prudently managed capital. We maintained our industry-leading return on capital and delivered one of the highest free cash flow results in company history by achieving 25% operating cash flow as a percentage of sales and trimming capital expenditures 9% from prior year. During 2015, we also raised the dividend 10% as part of the $1.5 billion return to shareholders through dividends and stock repurchases. And we accomplished this without using leverage, as we held net debt flat. 
Third, we never lost sight of the priority for quality growth. We signed 6 large growth projects for about $700 million of investment, including the largest in company history, to extend our hydrogen and nitrogen pipeline complex in the U.S. Gulf Coast and supply the Yara-BASF joint venture. Acquisitions also played an important role, with around 15 accretive deals being closed or announced, including the European industrial gas business of Yara to help the to another percent of global for the company. We recently announced the joint venture with GE Aviation to enhance our presence in the aerospace market and provide additional resilient growth prospects. And we continue to deploy our application technologies to find more usage for our products that enable our customers to increase productivity, lower costs and improve their environmental footprint. 
And finally, we recognized the cyclical shift in some of our end markets and quickly adapted with a series of actions and initiatives. The renewed focus on more resilient industries and synergistic acquisitions at a reasonable price will provide continued growth opportunities in a world that is cyclically weaker across many sectors. 
So collectively, these actions mitigated the current headwinds and better positioned the company for future earnings accretion when markets turn. But unfortunately, we're seeing many negative trends continue into 2016. 
When I look around at the current industrial state of the world, I don't see many things getting better, and a few are getting a little worse. The combination of excess supply and reduced demand continues to put strain on several industrial end markets. However, we have exclusive customer supply contracts with our cylinders, tanks and pipelines that are located at customer sites. The challenge is that we are replenishing the gases to these assets at a lower frequency due to our customers' lower production rates. But consistent with other prior industrial cycles, this will eventually turn and improve. 
In North America, the impact of lower hydrocarbon pricing continues to pressure many industries, including mining, oil and gas, railcar production, heavy equipment and general manufacturing. Furthermore, the stronger dollar has put additional strain on the U.S. manufacturing competitiveness. These negative trends can be seen in recent industrial production and PMI reports. However, we continue to see good demand in consumer-oriented sectors like food, beverage, automotive, health care, refining and chemicals. They U.S. Gulf Coast petrochemical buildout still provides good opportunities for new on-site contracts, and we are pursuing several bids, of which we expect to convert to new supply contracts soon. 
South America has not improved but rather worsened, which is consistent with our expectations. The combination of political turmoil in Brazil and the seasonal outages significantly curtailed volumes, which will likely continue into Q1 for the Carnaval holiday and possibly beyond. I believe the election results in countries like Venezuela and Argentina will bode well for future business opportunities, but it will take some time to see any impact on the ground. We continue to take appropriate actions to preserve the quality of the business, but frankly, South America is becoming less and less of a component of our consolidated results due to the severe currency devaluation. So the potential downside impact is less than prior years. 
Europe is stable and slightly growing in several regions. Commodity-consuming nations like Germany, Spain, Benelux and Italy have benefited from the lower cost of oil and weaker euro. This is evidenced by the strong growth we are seeing in our Port of Antwerp pipeline expansion such as the recently announced Total contracts. In addition to the positive growth across both cyclical and noncyclical industries, commodity-producing nations like Russia and those in Scandinavia are negatively feeling the effects, but we have partnered with some of the most competitive and lowest-cost producers in the world. So they're still running their assets in this environment, and we anticipate that to continue. 
Asia segment trends are quite different depending upon the country. Thailand and India continue to perform well, and we're seeing strong pockets of growth in both countries. Korean growth is primarily focused on the electronics industry, which has been in a strong cycle for a few years now, although certain areas are projected to slow. And China is the country getting the most press these days. Clearly, you have a situation of excess capacity across most infrastructure-supporting industries like steel, glass and cement. We've been seeing softness in those areas for a few quarters now, and that will likely continue for 2016. Consumer-related industries are still performing well in China, as we continue to see good demand for things like transportation fuels, food, health care, environmental solutions and plastics. Examples include our new project startup at [indiscernible] and a recent project signing with [indiscernible]. So we'll have to see how China performs this year, but the underlying growth rates will be lower than what we saw in prior years. 
So when you sum it up, we're just not seeing much improvement from the current weak industrial run rates. Given that, our strategic focus that we laid out over the past several months is still valid in this environment, and you can find that on Page 3. 
This slide shows the key elements of our focus to grow earnings and cash flow regardless of the underlying economic conditions, and we are still on track. 
Starting with the bar at the top. We're currently benefiting from the cost restructuring actions taken mid last year. And we continue to find new price and cost opportunities throughout our business. These are, and will, continue to contribute positive EPS growth. 
On the second bar, we are proceeding well regarding synergistic acquisitions. We still expect to execute $500 million to $600 million of acquisitions this year, with over half already announced. Most of these are in developed markets or more resilient industries, which will help enhance and insulate our business portfolio from some of the current cyclical trends. And we expect strong project backlog contribution for 2017 as some of our large, fixed-fee projects are slated to start in that year. 
So we've mapped the path to growth for our earnings, but for 2016, it's not enough to offset the combination of foreign currency headwind and the current trend of negative underlying volumes. I'll cover this further, including guidance, at the end of the prepared remarks. But first, Kelcey can provide more details on our financial performance for 2015.

headline: Praxair Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Matt. Please turn to Slide 4 for an overview of the full year. Overall sales were $10.8 billion, steady with the prior year, excluding currency and cost pass-through. Price attainment contributed 1% growth and was achieved in all reporting segme
componenttext:
Thanks, Matt. Please turn to Slide 4 for an overview of the full year. 
Overall sales were $10.8 billion, steady with the prior year, excluding currency and cost pass-through. Price attainment contributed 1% growth and was achieved in all reporting segments. Volume growth from projects was about half weighted towards Asia, with the remainder of the contribution in Europe and North America. The full year volume decline, net of project contribution, was driven by weaker base volumes in the Americas, primarily in the upstream energy, manufacturing and metals end markets. Globally, food and beverage, health care and aerospace end markets were positive with low to mid-single-digit organic growth. 
We completed a number of small industrial gas acquisitions during the year that contributed about 1% to the overall growth of Praxair. These synergistic acquisitions will continue to enhance our production network density in all operating segments. 
Operating profit of $2.5 billion grew 1% year-over-year, excluding foreign currency, from higher pricing, cost actions and acquisitions. As a result, we grew full year EBITDAR and operating margins to record levels. Earnings per share of $5.80 grew 3%, excluding foreign currency. 
Please turn to Slide 5 for an overview of cash flow. Through consistent capital and operational discipline, we generated strong operating cash flow of $2.7 billion for the year at 25% of sales. During 2015, $1.5 billion was prudently invested in CapEx for growth and density improvement. These investments are in our core regions and meet our disciplined investment criteria. More than half of the CapEx spent during 2015 occurred in North America, with the rest equally distributed to Asia, Europe and South America. During 2016, CapEx is expected to be even more weighted towards North America, given its larger share of the backlog. 
When our end markets and geographies are in lower growth cycles like today, we typically generate more free cash flow than periods of stronger capital investment since the majority of our capital spend is for growth projects that are only initiated with executed customer contracts. As a result, this morning, we announced a 5% increase to our quarterly dividend, which represents our 23rd consecutive annual increase. This is consistent with our policy to grow dividends each year. The remaining cash that we have after growth investments and dividends is directed towards share repurchases. During 2015, we reduced our outstanding share count by 2%. This was our sixth consecutive year of reducing the share count by at least 1%. 
Now please turn to Slide 6 for an overview of the fourth quarter. Fourth quarter sales were $2.6 billion and 1% lower than the prior year, excluding currency impacts and cost pass-through. Organic sales increased from higher pricing in most operating segments. Lower base volumes continued to be driven by the Americas, primarily in the manufacturing, upstream energy and metals end markets. This was partially offset by new volumes from project startups in Asia and Europe as well as global growth in refining, food and beverage, health care and aerospace end markets. Small acquisitions within all segments contributed 1% growth. 
By operating segment, North America's organic sales declined 3% year-over-year and 1% sequentially. The business achieved price improvement in the U.S., Mexico and Canada. Weaker volumes for manufacturing customers drove about half of the volume decline. This was primarily due to hardgoods, as consumers are reducing investment in capital equipment, given the uncertainty in demand and headwinds from imports with the strength of the U.S. dollar. The remaining volume softness was driven by upstream energy and metals, with metals down 16% organically year-over-year and 8% sequentially. This was partially mitigated by end market growth from refinery, health care and food and beverage customers. 
In Europe, organic sales grew 4% year-over-year and were down 1% sequentially. Year-over-year growth was primarily driven by price attainment in most countries, project contribution in Russia and higher base volumes in Spain. Sequential volume declines were primarily due to upstream energy customers. 
South America's underlying sales were down 1% year-over-year, as volume declines in most end markets were partially offset by price contribution, acquisition and growth in the health care and food and beverage end markets. Sequentially, volumes were down 6% due to further deteriorating industrial production and extended holiday shutdowns by customers in Brazil. This occurred in most end markets with the largest impact to manufacturing, which represents about 20% of Brazil sales. 
Underlying growth in Asia was 6% higher than last year and 2% higher sequentially, primarily driven by new project startups in China and India, growing carbon dioxide sales in Thailand and acquisitions. 
Surface Technologies organic growth was down 2% year-over-year, driven by energy and industrial end markets, and up 4% sequentially, driven by stronger aerospace coatings. 
Global consolidated operating profit was $624 million in the fourth quarter and grew 5% over the prior year, excluding foreign currency. We are seeing the benefits of our restructuring actions, price attainment and acquisitions. The fourth quarter operating profit and margin also benefited from a gain on sale in North America. Earnings per share of $1.47 grew 5% year-over-year, excluding currency. Operating cash flow was $791 million, represented 30% of sales and funded $387 million of capital expenditures. The company paid $204 million of dividends and repaid $203 million of debt to hold net debt steady for the year. 
Our project backlog, which we define as projects with CapEx greater than $5 million and associated with the fully executed customer supply contract, is currently $1.5 billion and comprised of 18 projects. During the fourth quarter, we signed 2 long-term contracts for new projects located in North America and Europe and started 2 projects in Asia. Existing backlog projects will start up and contribute to growth during 2016 through 2018, as shown on Slide 16. North America now reflects about 45% of the backlog. 
We continue to look selectively for tuck-in acquisitions in our core business, which are high-quality, low-risk properties where we can bring synergies to the business we are buying and we can achieve an attractive return on investment. During the fourth quarter, we bought 3 industrial gas businesses in the U.S. with multiple locations and combined sales of more than $20 million annually. And we increased ownership of an existing joint venture in Asia. 
And now I'll turn the call back to Matt to discuss our outlook and earnings guidance for 2016.

headline: Praxair Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Please turn to Page 6. Our full year guidance for 2016 is in the range of $5.30 to $5.70. While the entire range is below our 2015 EPS, it does include $0.42 or 7% anticipated headwind from foreign currency translation. The lower right of this slide, yo
componenttext:
Please turn to Page 6. Our full year guidance for 2016 is in the range of $5.30 to $5.70. While the entire range is below our 2015 EPS, it does include $0.42 or 7% anticipated headwind from foreign currency translation. 
The lower right of this slide, you can see the average 2015 FX rate for some of our major currencies, which were all much stronger than what the current spot rates are today. Excluding the FX impact, we expect underlying EPS to grow to be a low of minus 2% to a high of plus 5%. There are a few key drivers that comprise this range. We expect to deliver positive EPS growth from our price, productivity and the 2015 cost actions. Many of these items are already completed, and we have a high level of confidence in our ability to continue to improve our earnings going forward through these company-specific actions. 
We also are expecting EPS accretion through our acquisitions and share buyback program. These are good examples of contribution from our capital allocation process. We have closed several synergistic acquisitions and anticipate completing a few more early this year, which will be immediately accretive to our results. These are primarily tuck-in acquisitions that serve more resilient markets and enhance our existing portfolio. 
In addition, our excess free cash flow has enabled us to consistently repurchase shares without increasing debt levels. So we also feel good about contribution from these areas as most of them are already completed. 
Product volume is really the key unknown factor and, in addition to foreign currency, will vary the most in the near term. You can see the range showing more downside risk than upside. The to pend of this range represents our project volume startup, which we have good visibility into and assumes slightly positive underlying volume growth. The bottom end represents in the same project growth but with current underlying volume trends up [ph] negative low to mid-single-digit percent. As I mentioned earlier, this volume is tied to our existing network of pipelines, tanks and cylinders. So the contracts and assets are in place, but we simply aren't supplying them at the same rate due to the slower demand environment. We'll continue to take actions to improve on this range, but this is our best estimate at this time. 
Turning to the first quarter. We are calling an EPS range of $1.20 to $1.28. This range is down 10% to 16% from last year, of which 9% relates to FX impact. So we're anticipating underlying EPS to be down 1% to 7%. While we have the full benefit of cost reductions in our results, we don't expect that to fully offset the lower volumes seen primarily in North and South America. 
We expect Q1 to be the weakest for 2016, given the normal seasonal impact, coupled with the abnormally low volume trends coming out of 2015. We saw extended seasonal outages during the fourth quarter, and we anticipate similar trends for the first quarter. 
The first half of 2016, especially the first quarter, will be more challenging than the back half. However, we have developed a strategy around to this environment and have taken actions in anticipation of these trends. Our business usually leads these cycles, given the nature of our industry and end markets. We expect to lead the recovery. And while near-term trends will the pressure, we'll continue to take prudent and appropriate actions for long-term shareholder value creation. 
I'd now like to open up the line for Q&A.

headline: Praxair Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And our first question comes from the line of Mike Harrison with the Seaport global securities.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And our first question comes from the line of Mike Harrison with the Seaport global securities.

componenttextpreview: Matt, can you give us any color on the timing and kind of volume contribution of new project startups during 2016? It looks from your chart there like you're expecting maybe kind of a 3% to 4% volume contribution there at the high end potentially. And the
componenttext: Matt, can you give us any color on the timing and kind of volume contribution of new project startups during 2016? It looks from your chart there like you're expecting maybe kind of a 3% to 4% volume contribution there at the high end potentially. And then how much stronger does that get as we get into 2017 with the new project startups?

headline: Praxair Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Mike. So I think, starting with 2015, as you may recall, we had talked about 2015 being kind of close to 2%, 1% to 2% range in project to contribution. I'm expecting that to be similar heading into 2016. We have a fairly similar profile of startup.
componenttext: Sure, Mike. So I think, starting with 2015, as you may recall, we had talked about 2015 being kind of close to 2%, 1% to 2% range in project to contribution. I'm expecting that to be similar heading into 2016. We have a fairly similar profile of startup. 2017 is where we really expect that to step up, and that will be closer to the 3%, 4% kind of midterm range that we had given out a few years ago. So we do have a gap in 2015 and '16 on project startups. Part of it are things like the Chevron project, as you recall, that we ultimately ended up selling that asset and as opposed to starting up as a sale of gas. But I would expect '16 to be similar to '15.

headline: Praxair Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. And then you noted some CO2 supply outages in Latin America. What portion of your sales in Latin America come from CO2? And is that negatively impacting our ability to supply beverage CO2? Can you give a little more color on that?
componenttext: All right. And then you noted some CO2 supply outages in Latin America. What portion of your sales in Latin America come from CO2? And is that negatively impacting our ability to supply beverage CO2? Can you give a little more color on that?

headline: Praxair Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. I would say, first of all, when you look at merchant and package in total for South America, it's about 2/3 of the whole business there. CO2 is an important merchant liquid for us. And as you probably know, we generally feedstock -- we get the feeds
componenttext: Sure. I would say, first of all, when you look at merchant and package in total for South America, it's about 2/3 of the whole business there. CO2 is an important merchant liquid for us. And as you probably know, we generally feedstock -- we get the feedstock from various processes and industries. And given the situation in Brazil, from an industrial perspective, rates are so low on everything from refineries to ammonia plants, to chemical plants, that the CO2 sources now are actually going down for extended outage periods. So what's happening there is while we're still meeting the requirements that there are for food and beverage, it's causing us extra costs. We have to haul the product much further, dislocation costs. So yes, it's creating some inefficiencies in our system right now, given our supply source outages. And it's just something we have to manage and live with. I do hope that some of these will come back stream here, back in the first quarter. We're seeing a few begin to start up again. But that's something that impacted Q4, will impact Q1, and we'll have to see beyond that.

headline: Praxair Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. And then the last one for me. The pricing number in Asia was flat. Have you gotten to a point where you've neutralized the impact of the merchant overcapacity there? Where are you getting offsets to the negative merchant pricing?
componenttext: All right. And then the last one for me. The pricing number in Asia was flat. Have you gotten to a point where you've neutralized the impact of the merchant overcapacity there? Where are you getting offsets to the negative merchant pricing?

headline: Praxair Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: So in Asia, we still see some good pricing for either specialty or electronic assets, whether that's helium, neon. And those continue to contribute some positive pricing. The merchant gases of Lin and Lox and argon still are pressured. But as you know, we
componenttext: So in Asia, we still see some good pricing for either specialty or electronic assets, whether that's helium, neon. And those continue to contribute some positive pricing. The merchant gases of Lin and Lox and argon still are pressured. But as you know, we've been going more toward a direct model, less through a distributor model. So I'd say we're getting a combination of, I'll call it, mix benefit by shifting more direct. And also we are trying to take some price action. But the supply/demand imbalance, there's still an issue, especially in certain parts of the country. And we'll just see in terms of capacity. If we start to see some steel capacity come out of these Tier 2, Tier 3 steel players, that will help the mix on the merchant liquid.

headline: Praxair Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016

headline: Praxair Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's actually [indiscernible] Wagner on for Don this money. I just had a couple of questions in terms of the volume trends in North America. How much could you say the trend was driven by weakness in Canada and Mexico in the fourth quarter?
componenttext: It's actually [indiscernible] Wagner on for Don this money. I just had a couple of questions in terms of the volume trends in North America. How much could you say the trend was driven by weakness in Canada and Mexico in the fourth quarter?

headline: Praxair Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I would say, right now, one of the 2 biggest areas we're seeing some softness in North America, the most recent trends, would be in metals and in hardgoods. And the hardgoods is really mostly Canada and U.S., and that's just a function of bold less
componenttext: Well, I would say, right now, one of the 2 biggest areas we're seeing some softness in North America, the most recent trends, would be in metals and in hardgoods. And the hardgoods is really mostly Canada and U.S., and that's just a function of bold less equipment and less hardgoods going into some of these sectors like heavy equipment, energy, manufacturing. And also we're just electing not to sell some of these hardgoods, given the margins are just not attractive to us at this time. As far as the metals, that's primarily U.S. We are seeing some slower volumes from some of the import issues coming into the country as well as just some of the slowing demand on certain infrastructure products. But Mexico is mostly an energy issue that's played out in our results. It's been in our run rate now for a couple of quarters, almost a year. And excluding that, Mexico is still doing quite well. Canada is mostly an energy issue story, and that also has had some negative impact here over the last few quarters. There could be a little more risk going forward. Excluding that, Canada, on the eastern side of the country, it's doing fairly well due to the weak currency there. It's making their products more competitive. But I would say most of the challenges you've seen in the U.S. are either related to the strong dollar, which is hurting the manufacturing, or the impact of the energy metal side that's working its way through the supply system.

headline: Praxair Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Can you give us your thoughts on maybe, longer term, where can South America sort of be in terms of earnings power over time, given to where it's at in the past and where it is now?
componenttext: Can you give us your thoughts on maybe, longer term, where can South America sort of be in terms of earnings power over time, given to where it's at in the past and where it is now?

headline: Praxair Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Mike, as you may recall, we've actually included in the package the backup sort of how South America has been as a portion of our business over time. And it's something that -- with its height as a segment, it was almost 20% of the operating profit o
componenttext: Yes, Mike, as you may recall, we've actually included in the package the backup sort of how South America has been as a portion of our business over time. And it's something that -- with its height as a segment, it was almost 20% of the operating profit of the entire company. Today, it's slightly above 10%. So we've seen these cycles go up and down on the segment. When you look today, South America as a whole, as a percentage of the company, is approaching kind of 2003, 2004 levels. So I would say, if it continues on its path of shrinking, the shrinking is less severe than obviously coming off the peak in 2010, 2011. But if it does recover to kind of the levels we've seen in the past, that's pretty significant upside, both from a growth perspective in the top line but also the earnings because we tend to get pretty accretive growth when it recovers. So we'll have to see. As I mentioned earlier, I think you are seeing some positive developments in the government side, in countries like Argentina and Venezuela. It will take time to work through, but you're getting more business-friendly approaches in some of the governments there. I think Brazil has -- needs more time to work through their issues. 2016 will be another tough year. 2017, we'll have to see, but they do have an election in 2018. So -- but I think right now, it's at its lowest level it's been in over a decade as far as impact to our organization, and we'll just have to see going forward.

headline: Praxair Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. And then just a quick follow-up. You talked about acquisitions is an area that can help growth this year. You've kind of done half of what you hoped. Are the rest of them kind of smaller ones? Are there the bigger opportunities? Can you look at you
componenttext: Right. And then just a quick follow-up. You talked about acquisitions is an area that can help growth this year. You've kind of done half of what you hoped. Are the rest of them kind of smaller ones? Are there the bigger opportunities? Can you look at your JVs? Can you just kind of walk us through where growth can come from in this year?

headline: Praxair Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. It'll probably be a collection of smaller ones. As Kelcey mentioned, we did another 3 in the U.S. just this quarter here in packaged gas. And that will give us over $20 million of incremental sales, but it'll be many packaged gas, tuck-ins, primaril
componenttext: Sure. It'll probably be a collection of smaller ones. As Kelcey mentioned, we did another 3 in the U.S. just this quarter here in packaged gas. And that will give us over $20 million of incremental sales, but it'll be many packaged gas, tuck-ins, primarily in the Americas. But we do have some opportunities in Europe and Asia as well. And we'll just have more that will be coming through here, just given the situation that we have as far as some of the targets are being more, I'd say, open around valuation and strategic options.

headline: Praxair Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's spread all over. Normally, other income, we average per year $10 million to $15 million net income. And it's a combination of things like some nonconsolidated affiliate income that may be before tax line, gains, losses on asset sales, et cetera. The
componenttext: It's spread all over. Normally, other income, we average per year $10 million to $15 million net income. And it's a combination of things like some nonconsolidated affiliate income that may be before tax line, gains, losses on asset sales, et cetera. The rest of it would be spread across, but the larger piece is in North America.

headline: Praxair Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think your sequential interest expense, your interest expense this year has bounced around a little bit in that, I think, in the third quarter, it was $35 million and it was $42 million in this one. Can you talk about the volatility in it and what you e
componenttext: I think your sequential interest expense, your interest expense this year has bounced around a little bit in that, I think, in the third quarter, it was $35 million and it was $42 million in this one. Can you talk about the volatility in it and what you expect for 2016?

headline: Praxair Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. In our interest, as you can imagine, we have capitalized interest, the normal bond interest. But we also have the derivatives on all of our intercompany loans that we hedge. So the primary volatility we've been seeing has been the gains, frankly, th
componenttext: Sure. In our interest, as you can imagine, we have capitalized interest, the normal bond interest. But we also have the derivatives on all of our intercompany loans that we hedge. So the primary volatility we've been seeing has been the gains, frankly, that we picked up on these intercompany hedges, mostly China, and they're sort of one-off items. But it's just a little bit of noise that's creating that. On a normalized basis, our interest run rate should be kind of mid40s-. We have been doing some terming out of our bonds. So our interest to go up a little bit, it's actually improving the bond portfolio for us for being out much longer in terms of term. But I would say, modeling our interest probably mid-40s is kind of where we expect the next few quarters.

headline: Praxair Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then lastly, do you think that the direction of your capital expenditures over a 3-  to 5-year period will be downward or flat or upward?
componenttext: And then lastly, do you think that the direction of your capital expenditures over a 3-  to 5-year period will be downward or flat or upward?

headline: Praxair Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: For the last couple of years, it's been downward. And it's really going to be a function of the projects we sign. But when I look right now, we're seeing around $1.5 billion for 2016. I think it can be lower than that. We're taking actions to manage that.
componenttext: For the last couple of years, it's been downward. And it's really going to be a function of the projects we sign. But when I look right now, we're seeing around $1.5 billion for 2016. I think it can be lower than that. We're taking actions to manage that. If we sign a few large projects here, that could alter the course. So it's really a function of how many growth projects we sign, but the nonlarge growth, we're absolutely continuing to take efforts to manage those numbers down and in line with what we're seeing in the markets around us. So I think it can go down on its own, and then the rest is just a portion of new project signing.

headline: Praxair Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Duffy Fischer.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Duffy Fischer.

headline: Praxair Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: There's been a lot of talk about the difficulties of steel in China and the hope that some of the smaller maybe unprofitable guys shut down and they have their own air separation units, so you take some off-line that way. But are there also some steel pla
componenttext: There's been a lot of talk about the difficulties of steel in China and the hope that some of the smaller maybe unprofitable guys shut down and they have their own air separation units, so you take some off-line that way. But are there also some steel plants that are somewhat competitive that maybe have their own oxygen that would be looking to sell it in a tough financial situation like that? And if so, is that stuff that would interest you investing in China kind of at this low point or you're kind to pull back from investing in China today?

headline: Praxair Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think, in my mind, in China investments, i would sort of break it to 2 categories. There's investing in assets that relate to infrastructure, whether that's steel, cement, glass. I think, right now, that entire sector is just too much capacity. So
componenttext: Well, I think, in my mind, in China investments, i would sort of break it to 2 categories. There's investing in assets that relate to infrastructure, whether that's steel, cement, glass. I think, right now, that entire sector is just too much capacity. So there needs to be some rationalization, and I would see future investments in those areas being extremely limited. The other sector of the Chinese economy on the consumer side, which still are good investment opportunities, they tend to be smaller plants. They tend to be less capital-intensive. It could be things in environmental, in food. And that we continue to see good opportunities. But when I look at the steel capacity in China right now, our steel customers are, what I call, Tier 1. So these are the steel pipe customers there. They are very competitive globally. They're very well-integrated and they can withstand these cycles. There are Tier 2 and Tier 3 steel mills that have been popped up all over the country, and those are the ones, I think, from a liquidity standpoint and a competitive standpoint, are struggling. Now just the Premier recently here announced their goal to take out about 100 million to 150 million tons a year capacity. And just to put that in perspective, that's like these higher capacity in the United States, but they are looking to rationalize and take that out, which I think would be great. I don't know when it will happen, but if that could be accelerated, that should be very beneficial in a couple of fronts. It should reduce some of the steel production in some of the imports to other countries like the U.S., but also should help on the liquid merchant front. So in my mind, if those are rationalized, we would not have an interest in those assets. I don't think they're viable, and you can't run the air separation plant without some baseload cost effectively. So I would rather sit back and wait and let some of this rationalization happen that they've announced, and I think that'll be beneficial and constructive for the market.

headline: Praxair Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then a similar question for Latin America. Obviously, a lot of economic pressure there. Is there a chance that meaningful assets would be available in Latin America? And is that an area that's still of interest for you to grow in inorganically?
componenttext: Okay. And then a similar question for Latin America. Obviously, a lot of economic pressure there. Is there a chance that meaningful assets would be available in Latin America? And is that an area that's still of interest for you to grow in inorganically?

headline: Praxair Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, we're in Latin America. And in the '90s, when you had the last sort of economic significant downturn, we did exactly what you're saying, Duffy. We rolled up a lot of the steel mill assets, the air separation assets. We consolidated and grew o
componenttext: Yes, I mean, we're in Latin America. And in the '90s, when you had the last sort of economic significant downturn, we did exactly what you're saying, Duffy. We rolled up a lot of the steel mill assets, the air separation assets. We consolidated and grew our business fairly significantly during that downturn. In this downturn, we still are doing things like that. It's just the opportunity set is smaller. There's not as many as there was back 20 years or so ago. So yes, we continue to do it. It just may not be as big as it was in prior years.

headline: Praxair Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of P.J. Juvekar with Citi.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of P.J. Juvekar with Citi.

headline: Praxair Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: As you progressed through the fourth quarter, did you see a slowdown from month-to-month, meaning that was December much weaker than October if you take the seasonality out?
componenttext: As you progressed through the fourth quarter, did you see a slowdown from month-to-month, meaning that was December much weaker than October if you take the seasonality out?

headline: Praxair Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, the seasonality part is a little tricky, which you tend to find in weaker demand for production environments like we are is they'll extend the seasonal pieces. So they'll have normal shutdowns that they'll actually extend. And I think you saw a littl
componenttext: Yes, the seasonality part is a little tricky, which you tend to find in weaker demand for production environments like we are is they'll extend the seasonal pieces. So they'll have normal shutdowns that they'll actually extend. And I think you saw a little bit of that in certain regions where they took, for instance, the Christmas holiday or season or in South America, the summer holiday period. And they extended some of the outages around that. So I would say we sell the normal seasonal plus a little bit more demand reduction or production reduction. And we'll see how that carries into the new year.

headline: Praxair Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then if I look at your backlog, project backlog, it was about $1.9 billion a year ago. It's now $1.5 billion. And we know there is trouble in Brazil, the slowdown in China. It seems like global CapEx is slowing down. So what is your expectation
componenttext: Okay. And then if I look at your backlog, project backlog, it was about $1.9 billion a year ago. It's now $1.5 billion. And we know there is trouble in Brazil, the slowdown in China. It seems like global CapEx is slowing down. So what is your expectation for your project backlog going forward?

headline: Praxair Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: So this year, we expect that the startups we have slated might be another $500 million, $600 million that would come out of the backlog. So with no absolute change, that would drop into $1 billion or below. I am expecting to sign a few large projects and
componenttext: So this year, we expect that the startups we have slated might be another $500 million, $600 million that would come out of the backlog. So with no absolute change, that would drop into $1 billion or below. I am expecting to sign a few large projects and that should help take it back up. But you also need to look at the acquisition front as well. So we're stepping up what we spend an acquisition. So I do think some of the backlog that is declining a bit is being replaced by acquisitions. I kind of look at both of them equally in terms of avenues to invest capital to grow. So it is going down a bit, but acquisitions are stepping up a bit. And we've seen this in some of the cycles before. But holding off I've got about $500 million, $600 million that will come of this year, but we feel good about some of the key large projects that we have to help bring that up at least, thoughtfully, partially.

headline: Praxair Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Vincent Andrews with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Vincent Andrews with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Praxair Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Matt, if I just think about your guidance, I'm just trying to characterize it a bit. You talked about, in 1Q, you're expecting sort of the slow volume metric trends to continue from the second half into the first quarter. And then if I think about the com
componenttext: Matt, if I just think about your guidance, I'm just trying to characterize it a bit. You talked about, in 1Q, you're expecting sort of the slow volume metric trends to continue from the second half into the first quarter. And then if I think about the comments you made about overall 2016, the 2 big sort of impacts and uncertainties were foreign exchange and then volume. So if the second half weaknesses can continue to the first quarter, is it a correct statement to say that we need to see some type of positive inflection kind of into 2Q or into 3Q in order to get above the mid-range of your guidance absence some further help from maybe foreign currency reversing? Or is that not correct?

headline: Praxair Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think that's pretty close. If you exclude foreign currency to your point, I mean, the top end right now, if you started negative in the first half, you would need some positive in the back half to achieve the top end, which is little to no growth, right
componenttext: I think that's pretty close. If you exclude foreign currency to your point, I mean, the top end right now, if you started negative in the first half, you would need some positive in the back half to achieve the top end, which is little to no growth, right? To get 0 for the year, if you start a little bit negative, you got to finish a little bit positive. The bottom end of that range, essentially see the current negative kind of low to mid-single-digit trends continue all year unabated. So yes, that's kind of how we have it laid out right now. Obviously, if we get supplies to the upside on growth, that could help. And the one nice thing about this industry in general is when growth comes, it can come pretty quickly because as I mentioned, the assets are there, just a matter of refilling them faster at a faster rate are putting more molecules in the pipeline. So we'll have to see but they're cauterization I think it's pretty close.

headline: Praxair Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just as a follow-up. Airgas yesterday reported negative 10% hardgoods sales in their quarter. And I'm just wondering sort of generically if you think, you made a comment about some of the hardgoods weakness as a function of people just hold
componenttext: Okay. And then just as a follow-up. Airgas yesterday reported negative 10% hardgoods sales in their quarter. And I'm just wondering sort of generically if you think, you made a comment about some of the hardgoods weakness as a function of people just holding off because of uncertainty. I'm just wondering if you still think hardgoods is and we leading indicator of guest demand is going to be or some of that negativity has been skewed maybe by what's going on in oil and gas to such an extent that maybe such a clear indicator of the overall U.S. gas business.

headline: Praxair Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's been tough. We've looked on this, and it sometimes, it seems like a leading indicator. Sometimes, it doesn't. But I characterize hardgoods into 2 basic buckets. You have that equipment, and then you have consumables. The large equipment, as you
componenttext: Yes, it's been tough. We've looked on this, and it sometimes, it seems like a leading indicator. Sometimes, it doesn't. But I characterize hardgoods into 2 basic buckets. You have that equipment, and then you have consumables. The large equipment, as you can imagine, it's very large numbers that come in lumpy. And when you see large equipment purchases like automatic welders or cutters, that's when things are usually going quite well, and the customer base is confident enough. And furthermore, their backlog is big enough that they want to invest in automation so we saw a lot of that a year plus ago, primarily in the oil patch, but also in the whole center part of the country that serve the some of the manufacturing sector that built constant rate and other things for the oil patch. So we were seeing a lot of automated equipment being purchased. And also just a function of charges skilled laborers, skilled welders and so forth. So that part, we've had to lap. The consumables is the one that can sometimes move right with gas. You're going to use so much wire and contacts usually is some gas to use. So I would say that the segment has a little bit of a front-end indicator. We see that now, it's just a function of some of the consumables and just some other hardgoods that we personally are just not going to serve that market if the margins aren't worth effort at this point.

headline: Praxair Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of David Manthey with Robert W. Baird.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of David Manthey with Robert W. Baird.

headline: Praxair Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Matt, you mentioned that you're making acquisitions in areas that serve more resilient end markets. I'm just wondering if you could help us understand what you meant by that. And then second, as it relates to sort of generic U.S. tuck-in packaged gas dist
componenttext: Matt, you mentioned that you're making acquisitions in areas that serve more resilient end markets. I'm just wondering if you could help us understand what you meant by that. And then second, as it relates to sort of generic U.S. tuck-in packaged gas distributor, have the multiples that you're paying for those changed at all since the Airgas deal?

headline: Praxair Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, so first, on the resilient market. I can give you some specific examples we've already announced. So technocrats in Peru, CO2 business, primarily food and beverage, accounts that it serves; the Yara CO2 business in Europe, similar; a lot of food, be
componenttext: Okay, so first, on the resilient market. I can give you some specific examples we've already announced. So technocrats in Peru, CO2 business, primarily food and beverage, accounts that it serves; the Yara CO2 business in Europe, similar; a lot of food, beverage, to IIs, which application is going to a very different areas. Some of the packaged gas businesses that we are acquiring have specialty gases, large portions of specialty gases, and those tend to go into more industries like incremental, research, calibration gases. We've also done some medical acquisitions in Canada with our medical gases business as well as in South America. So those will be more into some of the hospitals in homecare areas. So those are kind of examples where we've gone deeper into what we'll call resilient industries that don't tend to move where the cycles of the manufacturing or industry. As far as the multiples on tuck-in, we really haven't seen much change. As you can imagine, we've been pretty disciplined on how we look at multiples and what we're willing to pay. And clearly, there is a large potential buyer that's going to in pause for a while here, but we haven't really seen much as far as valuations change on some of these deals.

headline: Praxair Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then second, I know your backlog includes only fully executed contracts, but can you talk about what mechanisms those customers would have to either delay or cancel those contracts to the extent they can?
componenttext: Okay. And then second, I know your backlog includes only fully executed contracts, but can you talk about what mechanisms those customers would have to either delay or cancel those contracts to the extent they can?

headline: Praxair Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So for most contracts, a cancelation usually triggers what's called a termination payment, which is essentially a net present value of all the fixed payments. So those are pretty big numbers, and you just don't see that of any project of any size. As
componenttext: Yes. So for most contracts, a cancelation usually triggers what's called a termination payment, which is essentially a net present value of all the fixed payments. So those are pretty big numbers, and you just don't see that of any project of any size. As far as delays, most of our contracts have some type of date certain clause, which will ensure that if the project's delayed, we either get paid day 1 regardless or we get recovery through the fixed facility fee through a higher fee due to the time loss value. So we do have mechanisms to account for that. Of the projects that we have right now in the backlog, there's no material delays that we can see, but we do have some mechanisms. Now obviously, if the delay's due to us, that's a different issue. But these are more if this is the customer's reason why today, we do not economic recovery mechanisms.

headline: Praxair Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016

componenttext: Yes, it's growing faster than the others. That's for sure. It's roughly about 1/3. Given the new announcement joint venture we have, we do expect that sector of that business to grow at a much more rapid rate. But it's roughly 1/3.

componenttext: No, no. I think the JV enhances the value of the whole business. And right now, we're doing everything we can to help that business grow, make it more profitable. But clearly, the more we can enhance the value of the business, the more attractive it is overall.

headline: Praxair Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Bob Koort with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Bob Koort with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Praxair Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Chris on for Bob. Just curious, industrial CapEx. Where do you view that? Where are we in the cycle? That's sort of building off from prior questions?
componenttext: This is Chris on for Bob. Just curious, industrial CapEx. Where do you view that? Where are we in the cycle? That's sort of building off from prior questions?

headline: Praxair Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm probably the wrong person to ask. I'm not sure. When you look at the cycles right now, you look at mining, oil and gas, metal, we're at a pretty -- a tough spot, I think, from a demand perspective. They're all in kind of a deep demand cyclical challen
componenttext: I'm probably the wrong person to ask. I'm not sure. When you look at the cycles right now, you look at mining, oil and gas, metal, we're at a pretty -- a tough spot, I think, from a demand perspective. They're all in kind of a deep demand cyclical challenge. From a supply perspective, metals is a little different because it's a China situation. So that's one that shortness of some capacity rationalization in China, could be the more difficult and that's our the right now. But oil and gas and some of the other traditionally cyclical -- I don't know, I don't know when they'll cover. The movements are pretty radical in a day. You're seeing some of these commodities. So we'll have to see going forward, but it's hard to say.

headline: Praxair Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then looking at your acquisition from your backlog, guys sort of mentioned sort of derisking portfolio. And is this reflecting the spirit of near-term opportunities are or a long-term strategic view?
componenttext: Okay. And then looking at your acquisition from your backlog, guys sort of mentioned sort of derisking portfolio. And is this reflecting the spirit of near-term opportunities are or a long-term strategic view?

headline: Praxair Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's a little bit of both. Clearly, the near-term opportunities are greater in some -- as far as growth, are greater in some of the noncyclical portions of the portfolio. So by investing in those areas, we can capture a greater growth in this current and
componenttext: It's a little bit of both. Clearly, the near-term opportunities are greater in some -- as far as growth, are greater in some of the noncyclical portions of the portfolio. So by investing in those areas, we can capture a greater growth in this current and sort of near-term outlook. I think there is also a long-term approach, which is just a further balance our portfolio. I mean, you go back several years, we took advantage of some high cycles in certain commodity markets, and we're not ashamed of that. We did quite well in that front. And now some of those cycles are at low points, and we just need to rebalance our portfolio like we do and be able to insulate it from some of the cycles. And when those cycles return, we'll be well positioned for that as well. So it's a little bit of both, and we need to continue to manage our portfolio around these trends.

headline: Praxair Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. One quick one. And where do some volume downturns across the globe, where do you see your merchant utilization rates sort of by geography?
componenttext: Great. One quick one. And where do some volume downturns across the globe, where do you see your merchant utilization rates sort of by geography?

headline: Praxair Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: So not too different than, I think, what we said in the past. But the U.S., probably a little over now, so maybe high 70s versus we're probably 80 a couple of quarters ago. And part of that this energy business was a lot of liquid nitrogen but also some a
componenttext: So not too different than, I think, what we said in the past. But the U.S., probably a little over now, so maybe high 70s versus we're probably 80 a couple of quarters ago. And part of that this energy business was a lot of liquid nitrogen but also some argon, you've seen a little weaker, given the manufacturing flowing in the U.S. South America is kind of mid- to high 70s. It is sounds fairly high, given what you're seeing down there, but a lot of our merchant goes to the noncyclical businesses, so it's food, beverage, health care. So those are some are holding pretty well in South America. Europe is also mid- to high 70s. We are moving a lot more product, and we've seen some pickup in improvement there. In Asia is kind of, I'll call, mid-70s, depends on the company. FM commodity in India, which were lower that number of it as the capacity gets loaded. China is a little lower especially now with the new year, Lunar New Year holiday tents a bit soften a bit in Q1, so that's in the mid-70s. So not radically different around the world. We definitely have ample capacity for when things recover.

headline: Praxair Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Steven Byrne with Bank of America.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Steven Byrne with Bank of America.

headline: Praxair Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Matt, in some of your earlier remarks, you referenced that hydrogen and nitrogen opportunity down in Texas with that ammonia plant the Yara-BASF is building. We understand that the primary source of the hydrogen is the ethylene cracker of [indiscernible].
componenttext: Matt, in some of your earlier remarks, you referenced that hydrogen and nitrogen opportunity down in Texas with that ammonia plant the Yara-BASF is building. We understand that the primary source of the hydrogen is the ethylene cracker of [indiscernible]. Is that the case? And if so, are your returns on the project like that meaningfully better than an on-demand hydrogen source like building an SMR for such a project?

headline: Praxair Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think, Steve, when you look at the overall goal, we have a very strong network of pipelines cavern in the case of a hydrogen situation to store as well as on-purpose production through things like methane reformers and air separation units on the
componenttext: Well, I think, Steve, when you look at the overall goal, we have a very strong network of pipelines cavern in the case of a hydrogen situation to store as well as on-purpose production through things like methane reformers and air separation units on the atmospheric side as well as by-product. So we will take by-product from core alkali crackers, et cetera, and bring them into our system. Clearly, having a blend of both, we believe, is a nice benefit because it is a lower capital-intensive approach. But you do need both because you have to give certain reliability and quality standards to the customers you supply into. So this is part of what's always been our long-term strategy in the hydrogen and syngas business, which is to have a combination of both on-purpose and sourcing. And it does help on the capital footprint. Now clearly, you need to make pipelines, you have to have compression, you have to have assets that can clean up the actual hydrogen source you're taking. It's usually not to the right period that you need. But it's all part of our overall strategy, and it does help us deliver the reliability and quantity that we need for our customer base. And it gives us speculate in terms of how we run our asset fleet connected to that whole pipeline. So I'd say yes, we're very happy with it. We think it gives us a very strong competitive advantage in bidding for new projects. And we're looking to continue bidding office network for some of the new opportunities throughout the whole goal.

headline: Praxair Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: And would you say that some of those opportunities might be the other half a dozen crackers that are under construction, are you looking at those as additional sources of hydrogen?
componenttext: And would you say that some of those opportunities might be the other half a dozen crackers that are under construction, are you looking at those as additional sources of hydrogen?

headline: Praxair Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, yes. We'll continue to look at those as sources, but we don't want to get caught too long either. So it's always a combination of managing resource and your sink [ph]. And so it's just part of that process.
componenttext: Yes, yes. We'll continue to look at those as sources, but we don't want to get caught too long either. So it's always a combination of managing resource and your sink [ph]. And so it's just part of that process.
