I would now like to introduce your host for today's conference, Ms. Kelcey Hoyt, Director of Investor Relations. Ma'am, you may begin.

headline: Praxair Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Elena. Good morning, and thank you for attending our first quarter earnings call and webcast. I'm joined this morning by Matt White, Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer; and Liz Hirsch, our Vice President and Controller. Today's pres
componenttext:
Thanks, Elena. Good morning, and thank you for attending our first quarter earnings call and webcast. I'm joined this morning by Matt White, Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer; and Liz Hirsch, our Vice President and Controller. Today's presentation materials are available on our website at praxair.com in the Investors section. Please read the forward-looking statement disclosure on Page 2 of the slide, and note that it applies to all statements made during this teleconference. In addition, please note that year-over-year and sequential comparison exclude bond redemption charge in the first quarter. The reconciliation to the U.S. GAAP reported numbers are in the appendix to this presentation and the press release. 
Matt and I will now review Praxair's first quarter results, including the current business environment and updated earnings guidance. We'll then be available to answer questions.

headline: Praxair Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, everyone, and thanks for attending. First quarter EPS finished at $1.28, which was at the higher end of our expectations. Cost management and foreign exchange rates in March were better than we originally anticipated. Global volume trends we
componenttext:
Good morning, everyone, and thanks for attending. First quarter EPS finished at $1.28, which was at the higher end of our expectations. Cost management and foreign exchange rates in March were better than we originally anticipated. Global volume trends were a bit mixed as we saw certain end markets improving, with others remaining at fairly low levels. By the second half of this year, we will start to lap some of the more difficult prior-year comparisons. So I anticipate year-over-year trends should improve. 
Starting in North America, volumes were weaker across our major industrial end markets of energy, metals, chemicals and manufacturing. Chemicals and downstream energy were primarily driven by extensive turnaround activity in the U.S. Gulf Coast, which we expect to improve over the next few quarters. Metals, manufacturing and upstream energy trends have been driven by the commodity price collapse, coupled with the strong dollar impact to our U.S. market. I expect upstream energy to remain fairly sluggish, as most wells are not being completed, therefore deferring the need for any nitrogen. We have seen some recent uptick in our steel customers, as a combination of import duties and lower inventories have resulted in higher production volumes. On the manufacturing front, while we've seen some sequential improvement in our on-site and merchant business units, U.S. packaged gas volumes have still been quite weak, especially hardgoods. In fact, U.S. hardgoods alone are driving our volumes down a full percentage point on the global results. Part of this is from weaker demand due to the slower investment cycle, and part from us not participating in some low-margin hardgood business. We've seen this late cycle reaction in our PDI business in the past, so it seems consistent with our prior experience. Looking forward, we may have a few more quarters to go with difficult U.S. packaged gas conditions, but the on-site and merchant businesses seem to be improving modestly. Canada continues to improve in the eastern part of the country from a weaker Canadian dollar, especially in the food, manufacturing and health care end markets, while the west and north continue to struggle from low commodity pricing. And excluding the energy market, Mexico is growing mid-single digits from a weak peso and a very strong manufacturing base. In South America, the volume decline appears to be stabilizing, but it's quite difficult to predict anything there right now. While there has been a flurry of financial market activity related to the political situation in Brazil, we really haven't seen much change on the ground regarding industrial activity. We did see some sequential volume improvement in merchant and packaged gases off a very weak fourth quarter. Brazilian markets of health care and food and beverage are growing double digits from prior year, while industrial markets continue to struggle. We're achieving mid-single-digit pricing in our merchant and packaged gas businesses but it isn't enough to overcome current inflation. So we are initiating new price actions for this year and continuing our cost containment efforts. Margins have eroded from a combination of lower volumes, higher cost and continued excess dislocation costs from CO2 sourced outages. First quarter is always the weakest due to Carnaval and summer holiday but we did see volumes pick up in March and we anticipate further seasonal growth into the second quarter. Europe has been steadily improving each quarter. Year-over-year volumes have increased a few percentage points, supported by project startups and some volume growth in Southern Europe. Almost all end markets are up over last year, with the exception of upstream energy. We've been able to capitalize this and achieve a steady improvement in operating margins, up to 19.4% for the quarter. We anticipate second quarter volumes will sequentially increase from project startups and the Yara acquisition. This acquisition will significantly grow our supply network and density for CO2, serving key Brazilian markets throughout continental Europe. In our Asia segment, we continue to see mid-single digit volume growth but a challenging price environment in China. The first quarter is seasonally the weakest in Asia due to the Lunar New Year, yet we still were able to achieve 6% volume growth, primarily from project startups. In China, industrial end markets continue to be plagued with overcapacity as the economy attempts to shift to more consumer and service-driven growth. We haven't seen much impact yet on steel capacity reduction, but we feel good about our Tier 1 steel customers as they continue to run their operations throughout this period. Other infrastructure-related industries are also struggling as capacity is being rationalized, so we have seen our glass customers lower their production rates. And while Western expansion of coal to liquid projects has been significantly curtailed, we have limited our exposure there and instead focused on coal to chemical projects with highly competitive customers in the East. As such, chemical and electronic markets are growing well, and we are increasing our focus toward food, health care and environmental applications.  Our Indian business is growing mid-single digits driven by combination of project startups and stronger industrial activity. Korea performed as expected from consumer electronic trends, and our Thai business has been growing in the food and transportation end markets. 
I'll wrap it up with our Surface Technologies business, which, as you all know, is a global business. PST serves 3 key end markets, aerospace, energy and industrial. The energy business has weighed negatively on the results due to collapse in oil price and subsequent reduction in coatings for oilfield equipment, although we have recently seen positive trends for coatings to industrial gas turbines. Industrial segment growth rate have also been lower due to global trends. Aerospace however continues to be a bright spot through our strong customer partnerships and air travel trends. We also have seen very high growth rates in our metal powders business serving the 3D printing market. Finally, we expect to start up our GE Aviation joint venture by middle of this year, which should improve the business growth rates. 
On balance, I'll say our first quarter trends was slightly better than we expected. We still have several challenged end markets and late cycle laggers, but we are seeing some positive volume trends in key geographies. And while our EPS is still down year-over-year from a combination of negative foreign currency translation and softer volumes, this is the second quarter in a row that our operating cash flow has grown over prior year. Furthermore, we continue to tightly manage our CapEx spending, resulting in 100% increase in first quarter free cash flow. 
I'll now hand it over to Kelcey to walk through the financial results.

headline: Praxair Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Matt. Now please turn to Slide #4 for our consolidated results. Overall sales were $2.5 billion, 1% lower than last year, excluding currency and cost pass-through. Price attainment contributed 1% growth and was achieved in most reporting segments.
componenttext:
Thanks, Matt. Now please turn to Slide #4 for our consolidated results. Overall sales were $2.5 billion, 1% lower than last year, excluding currency and cost pass-through. Price attainment contributed 1% growth and was achieved in most reporting segments. The majority of volume growth from new project startups occurred in Asia, with the remainder of revenue contribution largely in Europe. We continue to see solid growth at the more resilient end markets globally with food and beverage and health care growing 7% and 3% respectively. The volume decline year-over-year net of project contribution was primarily driven by weaker base volumes in North America, largely in the energy, manufacturing and metals end markets. Sequentially, volumes were down 1% versus the fourth quarter as the improvement in South America was offset by seasonal declines in Asia and the timing of customer turnaround in North America. 
By operating segment, North America organic sales declined 4% year-over-year and 2% sequentially. The business achieved price improvement from merchant and packaged gases. Weaker packaged gas volumes drove about half of the 5% volume decline, largely hardgoods. The remaining volume softness included continued lower upstream energy and metal sales year-over-year. In addition, chemical and refinery volumes were negatively impacted by the timing of customer turnarounds. Sequentially, organic growth to metals and manufacturing customers was more than offset by the impact of customer turnarounds, as well as modest further weakness in packaged gases. In Europe, organic sales grew 2% year-over-year and were down 2% sequentially. Year-over-year growth was primarily driven by project contribution in Russia and higher base volumes in Southern Europe. Sequential volume declines include the seasonal impact of the Easter holiday, as well as further weakness in upstream energy. South America's organic sales grew 1% year-over-year as price attainment offset the impact of lower volumes. Year-over-year volumes again outperformed local industrial production as growth in health care and food and beverage mitigated volume declines and manufacturing. Sequentially, organic growth of 8% included 3% from new price actions, as well as volume growth from health care, food and beverage, and even a modest improvement in manufacturing off of a very weak fourth quarter base. 
Organic sales in Asia were 5% higher than last year, primarily driven by new project startups in China to chemical customers and in India to metals customers. Sequentially, volumes included the seasonal impact of Lunar New Year. Surface Technologies organic sales were down 5% year-over-year and 2% sequentially, driven by energy and industrial end markets. Operating profit of $554 million was down 4% from the prior-year period, excluding currency. Higher pricing increased operating profit but was more than offset by lower volumes. Operating margin was 22.1% and the EBITDA margin grew 30 basis points to 33.3%. Earnings per share of $1.28 was down 3% excluding foreign currency. Through relentless operational discipline, we generated strong operating cash flow of $547 million, 22% of sales. This funded acquisitions of $63 million and capital expenditures of $323 million, about 65% of which was in North America given its greater share of projects in the backlog. In addition, the company paid $240 million of dividend. 
Our capital allocation process is consistent and disciplined. The remaining cash that we have after growth investments and dividends is directed towards stock repurchases. We continue to expect to spend approximately $500 million on acquisitions this year, including the Yara European carbon dioxide assets and the purchase of the remaining shares in our Yara Praxair joint venture. Given that we anticipate more capital will be allocated towards accretive acquisitions, we have temporarily reduced our stock repurchases. Our project backlog, which we define as projects with CapEx greater than $5 million and associated with the fully executed customer supply contract, is currently $1.5 billion comprised of 17 projects. During the first quarter, we added a project located in the U.S. Gulf Coast region for expansion of carbon monoxide supply to the chemical end market and starting projects in South America and Europe. Existing backlog projects will start up and contribute to growth during 2016 through 2018 as shown on Slide 13. North America continues to reflect about 55% in the backlog. 
And now I'll turn the call back to Matt to discuss our earnings guidance located on Slide #5.

headline: Praxair Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Before I jump into the numbers, I want to make a few comments about our foreign exchange rate assumptions. It's safe to say that FX markets are volatile and likely will remain that way for the foreseeable future. In years past, we were able to rely on spo
componenttext:
Before I jump into the numbers, I want to make a few comments about our foreign exchange rate assumptions. It's safe to say that FX markets are volatile and likely will remain that way for the foreseeable future. In years past, we were able to rely on spot and forward rates as good indicators for near-term future rates, and thus incorporated them into our guidance. However, these have not proven to be very useful over the last several quarters, as many currencies seem to be trading more in binary events than fundamentals. Speculation on political decisions or interest rate increases can move currency rates several percentage points in 1 day. In light of this, our current second quarter guidance reflects the recently improved foreign currency spot rates, but the back half of the year uses rates closer to first quarter average rates given the uncertainty. 
For the second quarter guidance, we are estimating EPS in the range of $1.32 to $1.39. Sequentially, we are anticipating volumes to improve from a combination of seasonal patterns and current run rates from March. We still have some volume headwinds in specific end markets, but I anticipate prior-year comparisons will ease by the second half.  Looking at the full year, EPS guidance is in the range of $5.35 to $5.70. We raised the range $0.05 to account for updated currency impact for the first half, but we then took the top end back down $0.05 in light of the North American volume trends, primarily related to U.S. packaged gas volumes. I believe we have a few more quarters of this late cycle impact, which reduce some of the upside potential for the next 6 to 9 months.  Capital expenditures are anticipated to be $1.5 billion, which is consistent with our prior guidance. We continue to manage capital spending prudently, so I hoped to improve on this number. 
In summary, our first quarter ended a little better than expected. Some of the macroeconomic headwinds have started to stabilize, but one quarter doesn't make a trend. Overall, we are executing the strategy, to optimizing the base business, prudently allocate capital for profitable growth and manage the things within our control to create long-term, intangible shareholder value. 
I'd now like to open up the call for Q&A.

headline: Praxair Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from P.J. Jimmy Carter from Citigroup.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from P.J. Jimmy Carter from Citigroup.

headline: Praxair Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: As CapEx cycle slows down around the world, do you imagine a scenario that Praxair's backlog continues to decline, but your free cash flow improves and you can buy back more and more shares?
componenttext: As CapEx cycle slows down around the world, do you imagine a scenario that Praxair's backlog continues to decline, but your free cash flow improves and you can buy back more and more shares?

headline: Praxair Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I'd say, looking at our CapEx spending, we continue to see, based on current numbers, probably 2/3 of it roughly is associated with growth projects. So if the assumption were that large capital expenditures of our customers would either be delayed o
componenttext: Well, I'd say, looking at our CapEx spending, we continue to see, based on current numbers, probably 2/3 of it roughly is associated with growth projects. So if the assumption were that large capital expenditures of our customers would either be delayed or deferred into future years, then yes, our free cash flow would continue to grow. And you've seen that over the last 18 months, frankly. We've had some very high free cash flow numbers, and a lot of that's been attributed to the reduced CapEx spend. But when I do look at the project opportunities, we still do see some U.S. Gulf Coast, pretty large scale projects that we're working on diligently. So I'd say, as the projects are coming in, they will be larger and lumpier than they have in the past. We are seeing projects that tend to be both process and atmospheric gases. So you tend to have larger investment than I'd say some of the normal investments we've seen. But to your scenario yes lower CapEx will mean higher free cash flow, and if we're not spending it on acquisitions, which are clearly another synergistic growth area for us, we'll just continue to raise the dividends and use any excess for some buyback.

headline: Praxair Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: And as a follow-up, on coal to chemical projects in China, historically, I think Praxair was a bit more skeptical in those projects. I think you said that they are now ramping up, and are they more valuable today and is that due to lower coal prices?
componenttext: And as a follow-up, on coal to chemical projects in China, historically, I think Praxair was a bit more skeptical in those projects. I think you said that they are now ramping up, and are they more valuable today and is that due to lower coal prices?

headline: Praxair Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, since we're not participating in any, I'll call it, at the mine of the mouth coal, especially coal to liquid, coal to synthetic natural gas or some of those coal Alton projects in places like Mongolia, we're not in there. So I can't speak to those p
componenttext: Well, since we're not participating in any, I'll call it, at the mine of the mouth coal, especially coal to liquid, coal to synthetic natural gas or some of those coal Alton projects in places like Mongolia, we're not in there. So I can't speak to those projects specifically. To your point, we did not participate in those projects. But what I would say we've seen on the ground in general is this. First of all, these are very high CapEx projects. They take a significant amount of capital for the gasifiers to basically gasify that coal and make whatever product you're looking to make. I think it's pretty clear and pretty well known that the liquidity situation for a lot of companies in China is not very strong. There's been a lot of stimulus that especially this most recent month or 2 that's not sustainable. So our view is if a project is permitted, there's a good chance it should be finished and built. For project that's not permitted in this space, I believe it probably will not get built in any foreseeable future. Then the question is, if it's built, will it run? Given the low coal price. And that's just the function, I think of the more profitable ones, with liquidity will run and the ones that may have some financial difficulties may or may not run. So that remains to be seen. But our customers that we supply, they're large global chemical players. They're mostly in integrated parks. So there's multiple integrated pet chem chain, and they continue to run.

headline: Praxair Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Vincent Andrews of Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Vincent Andrews of Morgan Stanley.

headline: Praxair Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Matt, on for Vincent. Just in North America, the 1% price gain while volume was down 5%, what's driving that? Is that perhaps a mix shift because some of the volume decline was in the lower margin hardgoods?
componenttext: This is Matt, on for Vincent. Just in North America, the 1% price gain while volume was down 5%, what's driving that? Is that perhaps a mix shift because some of the volume decline was in the lower margin hardgoods?

headline: Praxair Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: There may be a little bit of that, that mix shift. We have been announcing price increases. North America's one of the few regions in the world where they have publicly announced price increases. You may have seen some, through the press releases, so we a
componenttext: There may be a little bit of that, that mix shift. We have been announcing price increases. North America's one of the few regions in the world where they have publicly announced price increases. You may have seen some, through the press releases, so we are getting some price in merchant. We are getting some price in packaged. Clearly, there's a mix benefit with less hardgoods. However, there's also a mix hurt with less merchant going into energy, and what's called supplemental liquid that would go into places like metals that may run stronger or liquid argon that may go into places like stainless steel. So I'd say on balance, probably not a lot of mix effect. This is really more a function of the price increases. They are low-single digit and then when we show our price, it has a function of the entire revenue. So the number tends to show a little lower because you have on-site in the denominator and we don't count on-site as pricing. So we're still getting low single digit pricing in both packaged and merchant overall, and this I think pretty much reflects that.

headline: Praxair Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then just to follow up, are you seeing any pickup in packaged gas M&A post the pending Airgas deal? And have valuation ideas changed at all given the watermark they have established?
componenttext: Got it. And then just to follow up, are you seeing any pickup in packaged gas M&A post the pending Airgas deal? And have valuation ideas changed at all given the watermark they have established?

headline: Praxair Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I want to say from a valuation perspective, we haven't seen much change at all, and we're not changing our criteria, so I'll start with that statement. Yes, we did a few last quarter, 3 or 4, we executed another 3 or so this quarter, all U.S. packaged gas
componenttext: I want to say from a valuation perspective, we haven't seen much change at all, and we're not changing our criteria, so I'll start with that statement. Yes, we did a few last quarter, 3 or 4, we executed another 3 or so this quarter, all U.S. packaged gas. So we continue to see some good, small synergistic tuck-in opportunities, very consistent with the roll up strategy we've been performing. Clearly, there's some headwinds in U.S. packaged gas today. That also presents some opportunities for acquisitions. And it can make the valuations a little bit better. So we continue to pursue that, but we're still well underway in some of our independent rollup strategy.

headline: Praxair Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Mike Harrison from Seaport Global Securities.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Mike Harrison from Seaport Global Securities.

headline: Praxair Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was hoping you kind of addressed this in your discussion about North America pricing, but can you just talk a little bit about what you're seeing in underlying supply and demand dynamics in Lox/Lin and in particularly in LAR as we see maybe some improvi
componenttext: I was hoping you kind of addressed this in your discussion about North America pricing, but can you just talk a little bit about what you're seeing in underlying supply and demand dynamics in Lox/Lin and in particularly in LAR as we see maybe some improving utilization in some of the steel customers.

headline: Praxair Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, what I can start with were some of the headwinds we're facing and then talk a little bit about some pickup. With Lox, one area that's a headwind there is you tend to have, and I mentioned it earlier, supplemental oxygen on a liquid base as you can s
componenttext: Sure, what I can start with were some of the headwinds we're facing and then talk a little bit about some pickup. With Lox, one area that's a headwind there is you tend to have, and I mentioned it earlier, supplemental oxygen on a liquid base as you can supply the steel mills. So when steel mills run very hard, especially areas like tubular steel, they'll actually take liquid in addition to any on-site oxygen they have. Clearly that, on a year-over-year basis is a headwind. Those volumes are definitely down. Similarly, Lin is the primary product that we put downhaul for fracturing in the Oilwell service business and that, from Canada to U.S. to Mexico, is down significantly, given the challenges in the upstream energy business and the low oil price. So those are both down significantly in those end markets. Excluding those, we are starting to see some pickup, areas that are resilient like Lin for food, CO2, which I know you didn't ask about, but CO2 was actually growing quite well. We've been securing a lot of sources for CO2, if that is a game that's all about very integrated supply chain, and we're seeing a lot of strength there in food and beverage, especially things like our new CO2 business usage there for carbonated beverages. But other than that, we're seeing some moderate growth in Lin/Lox if you exclude those 2 sort of cyclical demand areas. On the LAR front, stainless is a little bit down year-over-year, we have some strong stainless last year, so you got some comps here lapping there, and met fab is a little down, given the trends I spoke about in pediotic. So from that perspective, I'd say, LAR is down a bit, but LAR is still tight over all. As you imagine, when you have on-site customers that are oxygen baseloads running lower, you have to make more premium argon. So argon is still a tight product despite the volumes being down in some of the end markets. And then liquid hydrogen is something that continues to be quite strong, we have seen a lot of applications there, whether it's for space exploration or areas in some of the hydrogen powered things like fork trucks. So hydrogen continues to be a pretty good growth product as well.

headline: Praxair Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016

componenttext: Sure, so I won't give a specific number, but consistent with what we've said in the prior quarters, we definitely do have some several steel customers that are running below and they continue to pay. This quarter is a little more difficult simply because you have Carnaval and you have summer holidays. So we always tend to see a few more customers even on a normal year excluding what's going on in the ground, get below end tops, similar with what you see in Asia with do you know you year, so that's what caused more seasonal dip. Put primarily steel customers, they are paying. And as you've seen from our numbers, we did see some sequential improvements especially from a very low December so I think that aspect has been pretty good. In fact, we have a couple of that below MTOP top last quarter and now they are above MTOP in Q1.

headline: Praxair Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, so I'll start at a high level. I think, Laurence, we are constantly reviewing our geographic portfolio around the world to evaluate, do we have the density that we believe to achieve the type of returns and the quality and reliability of the busines
componenttext: Okay, so I'll start at a high level. I think, Laurence, we are constantly reviewing our geographic portfolio around the world to evaluate, do we have the density that we believe to achieve the type of returns and the quality and reliability of the business model that we need. So that is always an ongoing effort. And as you stated, we entered into certain countries in the Middle East, and I would say the countries that we are in, we do have a fairly meaningful density model but not where we want it to be and we're not participating in Saudi Arabia, which is the largest country in the Middle East. So we continue to evaluate Middle East and see what options we want to take there, but that's something our portfolio will always evaluate. Russia is another area. We've been building some density given the situation in Russia today. We slowed that process down but we have built some pretty strong density in the Volga region as well as out in Katerinaberg and the assets that we do have on the ground there are running as expected and running fairly well. So those are 2 regions that we do see some opportunity to modify our portfolio one way or the other, but we'll continue to evaluate that. As far as Iran, we will clearly work with the U.S. situation there and what they allow with companies. But to say the least, the Europeans will have a head start on that just give in the U.S. relationship with Iran versus, I'd say, the European relationships will probably soften first. So we'll keep our eye on it, but it will be tough I think for American companies to get in there before any European companies.

headline: Praxair Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Bob Koort from Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Bob Koort from Goldman Sachs.

headline: Praxair Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm just wondering if you could, and perhaps areas is always well-regarded for your efficiency and productivity moves, and I'm wondering we had a pretty extended malaise in a lot of your markets, somewhat coming to the end of what you can do. How many mor
componenttext: I'm just wondering if you could, and perhaps areas is always well-regarded for your efficiency and productivity moves, and I'm wondering we had a pretty extended malaise in a lot of your markets, somewhat coming to the end of what you can do. How many more levers can you guys pull if we stay on this for muddling along end markets environment?

headline: Praxair Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think Bob, clearly, let's remember, we took out about 78% [ph] of the workforce here toward Q2, Q3 of last year. So we haven't quite even have the anniversary of that yet, but that was a series of actions we took. And frankly before we took that a
componenttext: Well, I think Bob, clearly, let's remember, we took out about 78% [ph] of the workforce here toward Q2, Q3 of last year. So we haven't quite even have the anniversary of that yet, but that was a series of actions we took. And frankly before we took that action, people were asking us that same question. What can we do, we've seemed to have run out of levers. I'm not saying that we would go to another action of that nature. We feel that the actions we've taken are well in line with the market we're seeing, but I'd also say that we continually look for productivity opportunities. As the markets change, whether volumes go down or volumes go up, it makes new opportunities in our logistics management. You're seeing mill rates around the world change quite differently, and it makes projects, some cases more valuable, that we may have not done in prior years whether it's an increase or mill rates or in some cases, a decrease in mill rates. And so as the dynamics change on these type of input cost for us, if the dynamics change in terms of the customers we serve, it can create new productivity opportunities that may not have given us a sufficient return under prior scenarios. So we're always looking at these changes, we're always trying to evaluate how long they'll be like this, and we attempt to take a prudent action. But we've had to have a lot of productivity just to sustain the margin levels we have. Every time we lose volume, it falls in pretty high margins. So we need to take a lot of actions in productivity and pricing to negate that effect, and that's what we've been doing. So we look to continue to do that. I'm not anticipating any headcount action at this point given how we're seeing the markets, but I am anticipating we'll continue to push productivity the way we always have, and we'll continue to try and find some opportunities around that.

headline: Praxair Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: And if I could follow-up, do you have any sense of a changing dynamic in sort of the industry growth rates relative to GDP or industrial production on a go-forward basis relative to what we had in the last decade? I hear from some investors some concern t
componenttext: And if I could follow-up, do you have any sense of a changing dynamic in sort of the industry growth rates relative to GDP or industrial production on a go-forward basis relative to what we had in the last decade? I hear from some investors some concern that we have sort of a basic materials in emerging markets Halo for the last decade that won't repeat and therefore, may be the growth rates of the industry have changed. What are your thoughts on that?

headline: Praxair Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think when we look at the growth rates from a high level, I still firmly believe it's consistent with how we laid it out in prior years, and I think how most of the industries laid it out in prior years. But the growth rates really is going to be
componenttext: Well, I think when we look at the growth rates from a high level, I still firmly believe it's consistent with how we laid it out in prior years, and I think how most of the industries laid it out in prior years. But the growth rates really is going to be a function of, I'll call it 4 basic things if you're looking at the top line, it will be price, and price tends to be, in my mind, more tied towards inflation. So if you do see some inflation here, that should help. We've seen in primaries with inflation, we have's in markets with inflation. It tends to be tied with acquisition activity. We are seeing more rollup opportunities in this environment, and we're an example of some of the acquisitions we're doing. And then it's a function of both projects and organic volume. So on the project side, it's clear backlogs are going down. Customers or potential customers are not making the capital investments they have. This is part of the cycle you see in the capital cycle. So that is something that if that returns or when that returns, especially in some industries that have been fairly muted for a while, like mining, heavy equipment and areas like that, that will give growth but if that doesn't return anytime soon, then that will be an area of growth that will still be a little sledges. And then finally, to your point, is this organic we usually use IPS a proxy. And to your point, what we have always found is emerging market IP multiples, almost always tend to be stronger than developed market IP growth multiples. And it makes logical sense because in an emerging market, it tends to be more infrastructure-related growth. You tend to have a lot more application related growth. That gets to that whole intensity of industrial gas per capita and that is a real thing we see. So when the emerging markets slowed and the commodity markets slowed, you saw a portion of the backlog projects be reduced as customers don't want to spend money. You saw the highest IP multiple markets be reduced, in fact, all negative, and the combination of those things really did make the, call algorithm Griffin weaker. But the question is the believe the emerging markets are out forever? I personally don't believe that, I think we're in cycles like in any other cycles. Some of the issues we have today are demand driven, there's 1 or 2 that might be supply driven but when it does rebound, you get back to those multiples you've seen and in prior years. Developed markets, in my mind, tend to be more closer to IP, a little bit above IP but that's kind of how I view it. So those are the factors of growth and right now, he has written a position where a lot of people are not making investment. Emerging markets are struggling and that's graded some dampening effect on our growth. But I do expect that will recover and return, when? I don't know but we've seen these cycles in the past.

headline: Praxair Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016

componenttext: Our next question comes from Duffy Fischer from Barclays.

componenttext: Yes, Duffy, I can maybe put this in this way, I don't want to throw 1 or numbers given complete uncertainty. As you know, general be another Fed decision so our view is basically that we thought, it is the weren't comfortable enough, to take spot rates and some forward rates as basted a few weeks ago to collect for Q2. Come June, kind of all bets are off because we just don't know what could happen with Fed decision and, frankly, we don't know what will happened tomorrow, let alone June. [indiscernible] But clearly, if rates are better our spark rates, all else equal, we will have better EPS than what the guidance says and that is holding our people. So there clearly some upside and rather not get into numbers because what spot rates, what day, what currency, there's a lot of moving parts there but you could probably do the math from what you get from our 10-Q we'll file, you'll see what the average rates were and you can plug in whatever spot rate assumptions you want, it probably would be a fairly rough proxy but it will get you close enough.

headline: Praxair Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, and then in general historically, hardoods have the words this much from the underlying gases, were the hard goods of the leading indicator or the lack indicator?
componenttext: Okay, and then in general historically, hardoods have the words this much from the underlying gases, were the hard goods of the leading indicator or the lack indicator?

headline: Praxair Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we always go around on this internally. My opinion is this. The equipment portion of hard goods the stand to be a leading indicator. Clearly, if people stop buying guides automated equipment, of our customers are not confident in their backlog of gro
componenttext: Yes, we always go around on this internally. My opinion is this. The equipment portion of hard goods the stand to be a leading indicator. Clearly, if people stop buying guides automated equipment, of our customers are not confident in their backlog of growth prospects, they will not invest in new capital equipment. So we saw that drop first first over the last, I'll call it 9 months or so. What we're seeing now is some of the equipment but also just consumables. And consumables, in my mind, tend to move with gas to an extent as far as how they drop. If you need glass shielding gas, you probably use less Contac, you probably use less wire, those things Centura and together. So I'd say, in this point, we have already seen some leading indicators on equipment and now we're kind of just seeing with gas in the consumables kind of down together.

headline: Praxair Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so we don't have any projects with Petrobras, in fact, we have very, very little business directed to Petrobras. What I would say the impact of the carwash situation and the Petrobras situation in general is just in an overall kind of paralysis on an
componenttext: Yes, so we don't have any projects with Petrobras, in fact, we have very, very little business directed to Petrobras. What I would say the impact of the carwash situation and the Petrobras situation in general is just in an overall kind of paralysis on an industrial investments I mean, Petrobras, like PMEX in Mexico, is a very, very big part of the economy. It creates a very large supplier chain network of many various industrial companies that supply Petrobras directly and indirectly. So there are many customers that we supply that supply Petrobras. And clearly, they are not doing as well. A perfect example, still company that makes tubular steel, they're not making much anymore given Petrobras. But in my mind, the situation on that has been baked into our results for a year now. That's -- they are sort of negative reaction from carwash and some of the curtailment of several quarters. Has already been reflected in several quarters. I think when you look at Brazil now, a question we get is what's going on with the potential impeachment. Would that make any difference? And right now, we just don't know, we just don't know. Clearly, the financial markets have been reacting positively. If. You look at the riyal, if you look at the Belfast bar, but we haven't seen much industrial change yet. But I would say, on an overall basis, the fact that they are trying to roll out layers of corruption is a good thing, and that should position them well for a long-term improvement in the economy. Can you sing some positive developments in Argentina with Macri coming in, with his ability to resolve some of the bond situation, his ability to Fischer bond, is creating a positive effect, and renewed interest and Argentina. So I hope with Brazil, we can get over this hump but it still going to take time to play out and we'll have to see. We're not anticipating much recovery in Brazil this year and we'll have to reevaluate for next year, based on how we see the next few quarters play out.

headline: Praxair Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from James Sheehan of SunTrust.
componenttext: Our next question comes from James Sheehan of SunTrust.

headline: Praxair Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Could you comment on the situation in Europe. Give us a little color on on what you're seeing in sort of the subregions there? Were we seeing kind of a gradual macro recovery and yet your volumes haven't really picked up. So when would you expect to see a
componenttext: Could you comment on the situation in Europe. Give us a little color on on what you're seeing in sort of the subregions there? Were we seeing kind of a gradual macro recovery and yet your volumes haven't really picked up. So when would you expect to see an improvement in organic growth in Europe?

headline: Praxair Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so we've been seeing, I'll call it slow and steady improvement, but very incremental. We've had project pickup. On an organic volume basis, we've been sing some good strength in Spain. Italy has not been that strong, but I'd say, overall, for Europe,
componenttext: Yes, so we've been seeing, I'll call it slow and steady improvement, but very incremental. We've had project pickup. On an organic volume basis, we've been sing some good strength in Spain. Italy has not been that strong, but I'd say, overall, for Europe, it's kind of continued to improve slowly, where we have the biggest headwind right now, has been in our upstream energy business, primarily around the North Sea and that has been a continual headwind. That's really offsetting some of the organic growth rates in the rest of continental Europe. So I'd say, when you exclude that upstream energy, we are getting organic growth in addition to our project contribution. So that part has been good. And you see some of it in the margins as well as we've been able to get the value of that volume contribution and capture with some improve margin. I'd say, Scandinavia in general is a little weaker, as you would imagine given it is an oil-based economy. We continue to see interest in investment and strong volumes in port of Antwerp area, which would make sense given the euro is a little weaker, given oil is a little lower and see shipping costs are much lower. And that really helps the competitiveness of that petchem enclave. And in Southern Europe,, like I mentioned, Spain has continued to improve here. We have to see what the election situation would end up but it still than improving. Our medical business which we have a fairly large medical business is quite strong across all your just didn't some recent a cure that one in Italy in the medical and also the Knox box in U.K. which is sort of goal. That has been good and I'd say, in general in Russia, the onset assets we have are running well as our customers are globally competitive especially in this lower ruble. And the merchant business and packaged business is somewhat soft, as you'd expect, in a stag inflationary economy, which is still large today. So in general, the Northern Benelux is doing well, Southern doing well, Scandinavia's weak, Russia on the ground, is still a little weak and anything upstream energy is quite weak. But slow and steady improvement is the general view we have.

componenttext: Yes so we don't want to finalize that here in a few months so we still going through the last remaining requirements. I don't want to anticipate any significant obstacles on that. We would still consolidate it, but to your point, there would be a minority interest impact with that JV structure so yes, that would be the way to model it. Inversely with Yara, we would take what today is  minority interest impact and that would go away with the consolidation of the JV and with the Yara CO2 that would obviously be just a brand-new consolidated acquisition. And with the Yara version, we just have one more real regulatory area that we are not overly concerned about, which should be fine. So I expect both of those buying back into Q2 should be finalize. Buts you'd never know what the timing and so we just need to keep it open.

componenttext: North America, I would say, metals, there are a few metals customers that will be below take or pay. And someone you see turnarounds in the golf, but again, that's more seasonal as to their turnaround, they fall below and we see that each turnaround season so there's no concern on that front.

headline: Praxair Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Mike season from KeyBanc.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Mike season from KeyBanc.

headline: Praxair Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Nice start to the year there. In terms of South America, volumes being down 2%, I just wanted to get a better feel for how that shorter flushes through. It sounds like your industrial business are doing worse and the growth in health care is doing really
componenttext: Nice start to the year there. In terms of South America, volumes being down 2%, I just wanted to get a better feel for how that shorter flushes through. It sounds like your industrial business are doing worse and the growth in health care is doing really well. So is the industrial part kind of more in line with the Brazil industrial production, you noted down 12% and you kind of have double digits from health care, food and beverages driving the outperformance.

headline: Praxair Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: We do have double digits from food and healthcare, probably 10%, 15% kind of growth rate. On the metals, yes, it's dropping at a rate, I would say consistent, if not more industrial production but remember, we have take or pay structures so they'll mitiga
componenttext: We do have double digits from food and healthcare, probably 10%, 15% kind of growth rate. On the metals, yes, it's dropping at a rate, I would say consistent, if not more industrial production but remember, we have take or pay structures so they'll mitigate that from its contractual standpoint. So what we're seeing it, from my view, on the industrial side, the customer volume levels are fairly consistent with what you're seeing that the overall results but our contract structures helps mitigate that. And then in the more resilient industries, we continue to see very strong results. And when you add that together plus the price, you're getting with some of the inflation impacts there. It is allowing the organic growth to still be fairly respectable, but we still need more work in that area. As I mentioned, we're still going to work more on the pricing side and we'll have to see how volumes fare out in these coming quarters but so far with a Phil, as expected, coming out of the March results.

componenttext: I would say, in general we have Yara encapsulated in more back half. I would anticipate much contribution and cuter here but from a back half perspective, we are accounting for a general docket of the acquisitions and I'd say, Yara is one of them but so, yes, it will be in there.

headline: Praxair Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016

componenttext: Our next question comes from Jeff Zekauskas from JPMorgan.

headline: Praxair Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: The industrial gas companies tend to have about a 1% year-over-year price increase. Is that price increase pretty evenly distributed across all of your industry end markets or does it turn out that it's more concentrated in certain ones where Europe prici
componenttext: The industrial gas companies tend to have about a 1% year-over-year price increase. Is that price increase pretty evenly distributed across all of your industry end markets or does it turn out that it's more concentrated in certain ones where Europe pricing is maybe above 1% and then in certain areas, your pricing is below. I realized that you have different geographies that you sell to, so maybe if you could discuss that in terms of the United States.

headline: Praxair Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, because my first answer would've been the pricing is more geographic depending on a lot of cases as you know. So with in the U.S., I would say, and we had this discussion a little bit earlier, there will be some mixed effect that could influence of
componenttext: Okay, because my first answer would've been the pricing is more geographic depending on a lot of cases as you know. So with in the U.S., I would say, and we had this discussion a little bit earlier, there will be some mixed effect that could influence of that when you have some higher-margin sales that are going away and we have seen some of that. So that could negatively influence of that. But I would say pricing is still very, very regional, it is within a couple of hundred mile radius, and it tends to be a function of any contracts that may be renewing and/or new opportunities that could be coming up in that region, and it will just be a function of the product supply available for that. But it's a very, very small transaction by transaction, and that's why every time we continue to look at this, what we tend to see is at the top of the house, inflation tends to be a fairly good proxy for it. There are some regional differences that could be driven either by geographic differences will in the U.S., right, we're product might be tight or on the leisure. And there could be some industry perspectives where for example a certain end markets may get extreme high value out of the product and the pricing might be a little better than, say, another in markets where there are alternate substitutes, a be different than into Shell Gas. So from that perspective, I'd say it is not too different from what you've seen in other industries but given that contractual in nature and given the proximity of the supply, beyond the top of the house, inflation still tends to be a good proxy in my mind.

headline: Praxair Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016

componenttext: Yes, I'd rather not go down there, Jeff. How people define mix in end of itself is a whole another equation so we tend to do straight volume on molecules and then the balance goes there which we consider mix because there's customer mix and there's product mix, right so there's 2 types of sharing. So rather than getting it through out of this call, let's just say, it's all in there.

headline: Praxair Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016

componenttext: Our final question comes from Christopher Parkinson from Crédit Suisse.

headline: Praxair Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: You clearly missed made some efforts to increase your exposure, food and beverage, health care, smaller defense, end markets, you saw cyclical of manufacturing has been weaker on a relative basis Brechtian you look at her end-market portfolio 2 to 3 years
componenttext: You clearly missed made some efforts to increase your exposure, food and beverage, health care, smaller defense, end markets, you saw cyclical of manufacturing has been weaker on a relative basis Brechtian you look at her end-market portfolio 2 to 3 years down the road, does that all all tie into your views of regional growth? And how should we thing about this when you look at your, I'd say, large project backlog versus your own desire to end market exposure or do you simply just think about it 100% from a return perspective?

headline: Praxair Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Clearly we continue to look at every market and we continue to look at it from a return perspective and opportunity set. So our focus on resilient markets doesn't mean we're ignoring industrial markets. What it really means is this. When we look out
componenttext: Sure. Clearly we continue to look at every market and we continue to look at it from a return perspective and opportunity set. So our focus on resilient markets doesn't mean we're ignoring industrial markets. What it really means is this. When we look out at least in the near-term and it's no surprise that there's a bit of a commodity and an emerging market retrenchment going on right now, that some of these more cyclical markets could take some time before they'll show any new growth opportunities, right. A rebound of lows were already connected to them. Our pipe is already there, our tank is already there. So coming off of a low and rebounding will just automatically get without focusing or without investment, right. The still under contract so there's no worries that the rebound we won't be capturing. The focus is more on investments. So where is money being spent today, there is a good amount being spent in some of these resilient areas. The growth trajectories in those resilient areas are greater, excluding the rebound effect on some of the more cyclicals so that's why our focus has been there. But it doesn't mean we're not focusing on all the growth opportunities we have, for example, in South America, we still see some opportunities for decapping, in some areas that would be cyclical and we've done that in the '90s and it was very successful for us and we do it again now. So those kind of things continue to happen, but when we look at health care, we look at food and beverage, we look at some consumer-related end markets like refining and electronics, they are growing well. We're focusing our applications technology, our salesforce and even some of our acquisitions towards those resilient markets, and they'll give us a nice compounded growth that's more based on demographics or more resilient trends than kind of ups and downs that we see in some cycles. So the view is if we have more focus on their, we have those compound growth rate and cycles return, you could get a pretty strong growth and a growth rate that is a little more stable. So that's how we've been doing it. By no means do we regret any of the exposures we've had. They served us quite well and they continued to serve us well. It's just that the growth opportunities in those areas are not as great right now, in this current environment.
