componenttext: Yes, I wouldn't say any specific target, James. Our primary objective regarding that is to stay within our current credit rating. So from that perspective, we might improve on that ratio a little bit here in the next couple quarters, but no specific target.

headline: Praxair Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Mike Harrison of Seaport Global.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Mike Harrison of Seaport Global.

headline: Praxair Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Was wondering if you could give us a little bit more detail on the North American metals weakness. I thought that we had been seeing some benefits there from the tariff activity that's going on.
componenttext: Was wondering if you could give us a little bit more detail on the North American metals weakness. I thought that we had been seeing some benefits there from the tariff activity that's going on.

headline: Praxair Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: We did. We saw some benefits in Q2 that lasted through Q3. But as we were looking at the weekly volume trends, we started to see some weakness as some of our major steel customers along the Great Lakes started taking, I'll call it more extended outages. A
componenttext: We did. We saw some benefits in Q2 that lasted through Q3. But as we were looking at the weekly volume trends, we started to see some weakness as some of our major steel customers along the Great Lakes started taking, I'll call it more extended outages. And what we can conclude from looking at their end markets is that there's a concern about softening automotive demand. Clearly, Ford's volumes are down. They just announced earnings. So it's more of a concern over just weaker automotive, and that's the assumption we're making at this point that, that trend is going to continue. Obviously, if we're wrong about that, there will be some upside. But right now, the assumption is that the weakening auction volumes to the steel mills are going to continue to be soft because of softening automotive.

headline: Praxair Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And is North America still relatively better than other regions throughout the world in terms of steel? Or is that no longer the case?
componenttext: And is North America still relatively better than other regions throughout the world in terms of steel? Or is that no longer the case?

headline: Praxair Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would say looking around the world, Europe is in pretty good shape. The mills in Northern Spain, the mills in Southern Germany are very good mills for those companies, and they continue to produce, supporting both automotive and the growth in other stee
componenttext: I would say looking around the world, Europe is in pretty good shape. The mills in Northern Spain, the mills in Southern Germany are very good mills for those companies, and they continue to produce, supporting both automotive and the growth in other steel sectors. So I would say Europe is more positive than it's been. Obviously, in South America, there's a lot of weakness and metals generally speaking, those volumes -- so the entire steel industry are down about 10% to 15% year-over-year. If I were to go to India, the metals volumes are up. If I were to go to China, I'd say the volumes are flat. And so while Q3 volumes year-over-year looked pretty decent in North America, we did start to see a softening trend. And again, we concluded that because of weaker automotive demand.

headline: Praxair Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. And then in terms -- you talked a little bit about the CO2 focus. You've done the NuCO2 business and the Yara acquisition. Your competitors got the ApCo business a few years back. Are there other regional CO2 businesses that would make sense fo
componenttext: All right. And then in terms -- you talked a little bit about the CO2 focus. You've done the NuCO2 business and the Yara acquisition. Your competitors got the ApCo business a few years back. Are there other regional CO2 businesses that would make sense for you to add globally? And can you also give us an update on how you're leveraging the new CO2 business in Brazil and in other countries?

headline: Praxair Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. We've added CO2 businesses not that long ago in Brazil. When we started up this hydrogen plant in Peru recently, there is a CO2 offtake as part of that project. We continue to look for CO2 sources in Asia, we really like to get the food and beverage
componenttext: Yes. We've added CO2 businesses not that long ago in Brazil. When we started up this hydrogen plant in Peru recently, there is a CO2 offtake as part of that project. We continue to look for CO2 sources in Asia, we really like to get the food and beverage -- our food and beverage business in Asia cranked up. So the answer is yes. I need we'll continue to look for good CO2 sources around the world. And the real key criteria there is that you have to have a high-quality source. It has to be competitive. It has to be a reliable source. And if you can capture those, you're in a great position to continue to grow from that source and that local market. If I look at new CO2, we have replicated that model in Brazil quite successfully. We've replicated that model throughout North America, in Mexico and Canada. And we're still looking at opportunities to do that in Europe as we speak.

headline: Praxair Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Laurence Alexander of Jefferies.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Laurence Alexander of Jefferies.

headline: Praxair Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Two questions. First, can you talk -- give us a little bit of extra color on the trends in North America packaged gases? I mean, is that down high single digits? And is the rest of balance of North America a positive? Or is -- what's the dynamic there?
componenttext: Two questions. First, can you talk -- give us a little bit of extra color on the trends in North America packaged gases? I mean, is that down high single digits? And is the rest of balance of North America a positive? Or is -- what's the dynamic there?

headline: Praxair Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So the U.S. packaged gas business, year-over-year, is down mid-single digits. The gas part, I'll call it gas or another, is down low single digits. Hardgoods is down mid-teens, and that's year-over-year. And then sequentially, it's down low single digits.
componenttext: So the U.S. packaged gas business, year-over-year, is down mid-single digits. The gas part, I'll call it gas or another, is down low single digits. Hardgoods is down mid-teens, and that's year-over-year. And then sequentially, it's down low single digits. So if you recall, we had a very nice step-up Q2 over Q1 in the packaged gas business. We were hoping that was going to continue through Q3, possibly grow. Would happen in July and August. And I've heard other vendors talk about this. It just was very, very weak in July and August. And September did get a little better sequentially, but not enough to really give us a lot of optimism in terms of the run rates. That's why we decided to take the cost actions that we did. What's behind that? Obviously, the whole energy supply chain continued to draw down throughout the course of the year. Commodities continued to be weak. Ag continues to be weak. Anything -- any producer that's driven by exports is penalized by the strong dollar. So mining continues to be weak. So just not enough going on from an end markets standpoint. We do have some positive segments, obviously, especially gases does better. Hospitals does better, others like that. But the major end markets that are metal fabrication-driven, railcar production was off. You heard me talk earlier about diesel demand being weaker. That's because less product is being moved from coast to coast. So that whole sector has been weak. And essentially, what we did, we just carried that run rate forward into Q4 and assumed that we weren't going to see any help in Q4. And quite possibly, as we get closer to the holidays, we may start to see extended shutdowns in the U.S. and probably will in Brazil, but we may start to see that in the U.S. as well.

headline: Praxair Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then I guess, actually the strength year-over-year in food and beverage, was there just a couple of projects that came on stream? Or what drove that?
componenttext: And then I guess, actually the strength year-over-year in food and beverage, was there just a couple of projects that came on stream? Or what drove that?

headline: Praxair Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's been a focus. is great when you got a strategy that actually gets implemented, in this case, that's what's happened around the world. And lot of it has to do with working on finding good CO2 sources, which we've been able to do in the U.S. You heard
componenttext: It's been a focus. is great when you got a strategy that actually gets implemented, in this case, that's what's happened around the world. And lot of it has to do with working on finding good CO2 sources, which we've been able to do in the U.S. You heard me talk about this earlier in other parts of the world. And then just focusing on continuing to develop that segment, take applications like the new CO2 business model, migrate that where we can. So while our core markets have been very weak, and we've been talking about that, markets like food and beverage and health care have been there for us. They're not too far from what we've been doing historically, so we just put a big focus on it, and we're starting to see some benefits.

headline: Praxair Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of David Begleiter of Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of David Begleiter of Deutsche Bank.

headline: Praxair Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Steve, on the M&A front, x Linde, as packaged gas demand slows, are you seeing increased opportunities on the M&A front in U.S. packaged gases?
componenttext: Steve, on the M&A front, x Linde, as packaged gas demand slows, are you seeing increased opportunities on the M&A front in U.S. packaged gases?

headline: Praxair Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would say -- I wouldn't say necessarily increasing. I mean, there's -- we always have a pipeline of opportunities that we're going through. I think what typically happens, these are family-owned businesses. When they start to see -- they always want to
componenttext: I would say -- I wouldn't say necessarily increasing. I mean, there's -- we always have a pipeline of opportunities that we're going through. I think what typically happens, these are family-owned businesses. When they start to see -- they always want to sell at the peak, right? They always want to sell when they have their peak EBITDAs and get out right before the downturn. Well, they were too late to do that. And so I would say that the pipeline of opportunities have been about the same. It's the same today as it's been pretty much all year. And we have few things we're working on and hopefully, we'll have some things to talk about going forward.

headline: Praxair Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Fair enough. And also, are you seeing any opportunities in buying ASUs or other people hydrogen plants on a one-off basis?
componenttext: Fair enough. And also, are you seeing any opportunities in buying ASUs or other people hydrogen plants on a one-off basis?

headline: Praxair Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: These are things we work on all the time. It's kind of like you heard me talk about acquisitions. You look at 20 the new 2[ph]. And you always have to be careful whenever a customer all of a sudden wants to talk to you about a decaf, which a lot of times
componenttext: These are things we work on all the time. It's kind of like you heard me talk about acquisitions. You look at 20 the new 2[ph]. And you always have to be careful whenever a customer all of a sudden wants to talk to you about a decaf, which a lot of times is a leading indicator they're having cash flow problems. But these are things that we look at. If there's enough value that can be created between energy efficiency, perhaps merchant liquid offtake, increased reliability, those types of things. If there's enough value that can be created, then there's a chance that they can -- we can go forward and do something like a DCAP. But if they start discussion or the conversation off with you got to do better than my cost of capital well, we're not interested in that. We're not a bank.

headline: Praxair Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Chris Parkinson of Credit Suisse.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Chris Parkinson of Credit Suisse.

headline: Praxair Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Manufacturing in the U.S. appear to be stabilizing a little bit last quarter, but it appears that there's a little more bit of a slowdown some choppiness in 3Q. So can you just comment on how this has trended over the last few months, particularly versus
componenttext: Manufacturing in the U.S. appear to be stabilizing a little bit last quarter, but it appears that there's a little more bit of a slowdown some choppiness in 3Q. So can you just comment on how this has trended over the last few months, particularly versus some of the shut-ins you saw within refinery and steel? And then just some general expectations as we head into 2017.

headline: Praxair Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, it's a lot like what I commented on earlier. July and August was very weak. September, a little better. I talked about the end market trends that's affecting that. We are much more exposed to metal fabrication. So when you look at that overall, inve
componenttext: Well, it's a lot like what I commented on earlier. July and August was very weak. September, a little better. I talked about the end market trends that's affecting that. We are much more exposed to metal fabrication. So when you look at that overall, investor production report you got to go down there and look at the sublines to really understand what's going on. So -- and from a steel perspective, I think it's what we've been saying since the beginning of time. It's so important to select the right project with the right customer to make sure that the asset that you're going to be supplying over a long-term contract is a competitive asset on a world scale. And where we've got all those decisions right, and we worked very hard to do that historically. Things are fine. They're operating. They're paying the take or pays. But if you ever -- if we ever got a feel from that, we have, unfortunately, then we people suffer from plans that have been idled or shut down.

headline: Praxair Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just a quick follow-up. You've continued to outperform the macro in Brazil. And obviously, it seems F&B and health care appear to be doing well in the region. Can you just comment a little more about the sequential trends and then just the general out
componenttext: And just a quick follow-up. You've continued to outperform the macro in Brazil. And obviously, it seems F&B and health care appear to be doing well in the region. Can you just comment a little more about the sequential trends and then just the general outlook that you're seeing across Latin America? Is it just basically just bouncing off the bottom, but not necessarily getting worse? And do you expect that to even get modestly better in 2017?

headline: Praxair Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's a great question. I wish I could give you a highly confident answer. I'll just tell you that we saw the manufacturing kind of continue to weaken in Brazil. There are pockets of Brazil that do okay. Pulp and paper does fine. Obviously, Embraer that we
componenttext: It's a great question. I wish I could give you a highly confident answer. I'll just tell you that we saw the manufacturing kind of continue to weaken in Brazil. There are pockets of Brazil that do okay. Pulp and paper does fine. Obviously, Embraer that we don't supply a lot to, but they do fine. Agriculture does fine. People that are shipping slabs -- steel slabs out of Brazil to go to other places, those volumes are fine. But we did continue to see the manufacturing sector continue to weaken. My -- our concern and what's reflected in the guidance that Matt gave us as we go into the holidays, they'll do what they did last year. They'll take extended shutdowns beginning early December. It might not come up that quickly. So you -- the good news is we have -- we've removed the political instability. I have President Timber, and so we don't have all that drama. But then again, they have some work to do. Interest rates -- the steel grade [ph] is 14%. Inflation is like 8% or 9%, so that needs to be brought under control. That is their intention. As they do that, we expect to see the economy rebound, but that needs to happen. And the people that I've talked to on the ground in Brazil, and I'm focusing on my comments on Brazil, believe that '17 will be a little bit better because they believe it's bottomed. So I think it remains to be seen. And I want to watch it very carefully this quarter and beginning next year, but in terms of what needs to happen, operating margins is back to 20% range as we need some lift in manufacturing, which is merchant liquid business. That's the packaged gas business. And that's very much tied to manufacturing. Just to give you a couple indicators. Our automotive production is down 40% over the last 2 years. 4-0. Capital goods are down 35%. So it that feels like those of bottomed, but they're extremely low levels. So hopefully, north is the only direction we can go from here, but it remains to be seen.

headline: Praxair Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Michael Sison of KeyBanc Capital.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Michael Sison of KeyBanc Capital.

headline: Praxair Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Steve, when you think about '17, it kind of sound like in your opening remarks that you feel better about getting earnings growth back on pack -- on pass with new projects and cost savings and your strong free cash flow. Any sort of color when you think a
componenttext: Steve, when you think about '17, it kind of sound like in your opening remarks that you feel better about getting earnings growth back on pack -- on pass with new projects and cost savings and your strong free cash flow. Any sort of color when you think about '17? I know it's a little bit early, but just on what you can control to grow earnings next year?

headline: Praxair Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'll give you a little bit, but again, we'll really want to see fourth quarter and really want to see the start of the year because the wild card really is base volume, and it's not just base volume. It's the composition of the base volume because no
componenttext: Yes, I'll give you a little bit, but again, we'll really want to see fourth quarter and really want to see the start of the year because the wild card really is base volume, and it's not just base volume. It's the composition of the base volume because not all volume is created equal from a profitability standpoint, right? When you're OL services up 80%, that's high-margin business. Brazil manufacturing, weak. That's high-margin business. Metals that we serve off our oxygen pipeline, it's all high-margin business. So the rent rates that we're going to see and expect to see are going to be very important in terms of how we think about profitability next year. So it's not just the absolute base volume number, it's the composition of the base volume. But just a couple other things I'll add to that. Obviously, we're going to have some benefit from the restructuring actions that we just took in $45 million will translate to about a 2% EPS lift. We're going to have greater contributions from large projects than we've had in prior years. Now a lot of that is second half, just about all of it is second half loaded. But assuming they come up when I believe they will, and we have very strong contracts there that will protect us, that'll be stronger contribution than we've seen. Acquisitions will be higher, just on a carryover basis, from the Yara acquisitions. And then price, we always seem to find a way to eke out at least 1%. That will be my expectation going forward next year. So I think the wild card is going to be the base volume run rate composition of the base volume, and we should assume from that when we give you guidance.

headline: Praxair Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And as a follow-up, it does sound like the backlog is getting a little bit better sequentially as we head into the end of the year. Can you maybe talk about -- I mean, you did note that there are Gulf Coast looks pretty good in terms of activity. A
componenttext: Great. And as a follow-up, it does sound like the backlog is getting a little bit better sequentially as we head into the end of the year. Can you maybe talk about -- I mean, you did note that there are Gulf Coast looks pretty good in terms of activity. Any other areas in the world that activity is picking up?

headline: Praxair Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. Well, I don't mean to be so curt, but I don't. I mean, the U.S. Gulf Coast, that's a secular-driven activity. These projects works for years. We've been working on it for years, and it's based on low-cost natural gas. And it's based on the infrastruct
componenttext: No. Well, I don't mean to be so curt, but I don't. I mean, the U.S. Gulf Coast, that's a secular-driven activity. These projects works for years. We've been working on it for years, and it's based on low-cost natural gas. And it's based on the infrastructure being there in place. And just the strength of the opportunity slate that we have, I said today 2/3 of the backlog when we start off the year, is going to be in the U.S. Gulf Coast. That percent is going to -- I project is going to go up over the next couple years. So unless the commodity market reverts and you see some dramatic improvement in economic activity in some of the emerging markets around the world, I really don't expect to see hardly anything in the way of new proposal activity other than maybe a refinery project here or there as places like -- places in Asia and also in other parts of the world need more transportation, fuel is cleaner, fuel all of that, I expect we might see some refinery opportunities. But as far as core ASUs that are tied to some of the basic market that we supply, I really don't expect to see much in the way activity. And you've heard me say this, I don't think China needs another plant of any kind. I think they have enough capacity for a long time.

headline: Praxair Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Vincent Andrews of Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Vincent Andrews of Morgan Stanley.

headline: Praxair Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a question on the restructuring. It sounds like from your answers to a different question that the slowdown in activity recently sort of was the catalyst that drove the restructuring program. I'm just wondering as you think about the size of that, an
componenttext: Just a question on the restructuring. It sounds like from your answers to a different question that the slowdown in activity recently sort of was the catalyst that drove the restructuring program. I'm just wondering as you think about the size of that, and you'd also made some comments about wanting to be -- not wanting to do too much. Is there a Phase 2 of restructuring that could potentially come if the environment doesn't get better as we move through '17? Or how should we be thinking about that?

headline: Praxair Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think environment stays where it is, there would not be any other action. And I really do not want to take another action. We took one last year, and we had to do it again this year because of just the extreme weakness that we saw in South America. And
componenttext: I think environment stays where it is, there would not be any other action. And I really do not want to take another action. We took one last year, and we had to do it again this year because of just the extreme weakness that we saw in South America. And Matt already made his comments in U.S., other parts of the world. So there's not a Phase 2 plan. I think you always have to realize that the world can change, markets can change, and you can never really say you we're not doing restructuring because you're going to have to react to whatever the market gives you. But based on what I see today, I don't expect or there would not be a Phase 2 to what we just announced.

headline: Praxair Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just a quick one on pricing in LatAm. I presume you're starting to see the currency go the other way. Is that kind of inhibits your ability to kind of reprice for the sort of the currency mess over the last few years or not at all?
componenttext: Okay. And then just a quick one on pricing in LatAm. I presume you're starting to see the currency go the other way. Is that kind of inhibits your ability to kind of reprice for the sort of the currency mess over the last few years or not at all?

headline: Praxair Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's not going to inhibit it. I mean, inflation is still high there, so we have to cover inflation. And in fact, we need price and productivity to combat inflation down there. So we're going to have to price to the inflationary market. That still exists
componenttext: That's not going to inhibit it. I mean, inflation is still high there, so we have to cover inflation. And in fact, we need price and productivity to combat inflation down there. So we're going to have to price to the inflationary market. That still exists. I know it's strange to talk about 8% or 9% inflation and the rest of the world is seeing deflation. But that's just the facts of what's taking place there. And we don't talk about this a lot, but we do have competitors there that are struggling. So that doesn't make some of our price objectives that easy to attain sometimes. But we have a -- we have an organization there that pricing is important, and they know how to get it, and they know how to manage it on a very granular and practical level. And they've done a great job. I expect them to continue to do a great job.

headline: Praxair Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Don Carson of Susquehanna.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Don Carson of Susquehanna.

headline: Praxair Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Steve, a question on health care. In your slide, Slide 5, you talked about resilient end markets. It looked for a while that you might be back in U.S. home health care. That's a market you exited many years ago due to Medicare reimbursement issues. So I'm
componenttext: Steve, a question on health care. In your slide, Slide 5, you talked about resilient end markets. It looked for a while that you might be back in U.S. home health care. That's a market you exited many years ago due to Medicare reimbursement issues. So I'm just wondering what's changed? What makes that market sort of more attractive to you now?

headline: Praxair Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, as we look around the world, hospital gases has always been attractive to us, and that's unchanged from what we talked about historically. The hospital business really depends on the local market. Some markets are -- have a favorable conditions to p
componenttext: Well, as we look around the world, hospital gases has always been attractive to us, and that's unchanged from what we talked about historically. The hospital business really depends on the local market. Some markets are -- have a favorable conditions to participate in the home care market. Others do not, so we look at that very carefully. But hospital universally has been a good business. And I said I wasn't going to comment further on Linde, and I think that was question was alluding to. But I've been out in the U.S. home care market for a while I think we exited in 2010, something like that. And I know that they've been through many, many rounds of auctions, competitive bidding, and that has driven the pricing down considerably. But I also understand that that's probably run its course. And so if you ever want to participate in the U.S. home care market, now will be a much better time to start entertaining those thoughts than say 5 years ago before. The onslaught started in terms of competitive bidding.

headline: Praxair Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then a follow-up on U.S. merchant. I assume that your merchant operating rates are still in the high 70s, low 80s. Is there any -- and it's been that way for, I guess, the last 5, 6 years. Is there anyway to rationalize your U.S. merchant capacity? Or
componenttext: And then a follow-up on U.S. merchant. I assume that your merchant operating rates are still in the high 70s, low 80s. Is there any -- and it's been that way for, I guess, the last 5, 6 years. Is there anyway to rationalize your U.S. merchant capacity? Or is that really concluded by logistics for entrance?

headline: Praxair Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I mean, that's something we look at all the time in terms of -- based on end market demand trends. Should we be running this plant harder? Should we idle this plant? So that's kind of something we look at on an ongoing basis. You are correct in terms of w
componenttext: I mean, that's something we look at all the time in terms of -- based on end market demand trends. Should we be running this plant harder? Should we idle this plant? So that's kind of something we look at on an ongoing basis. You are correct in terms of where the capacity utilization to reside. I think we touched 80% in the U.S. this quarter. And we're talking about LOX/LIN. So obviously, it really depends on which product you're talking about. LOX/LIN is the 2 largest products. Argon is certainly a higher capacity utilization than that. And if we look around the world, we're probably -- the answer is probably 70s no matter what country you look at from a capacity utilization standpoint. So there is capacity there to serve growth as it materializes. And in the U.S., I wouldn't say there's a lot that we can do to rationalize capacity. We already have swap agreements -- product swap agreements with our competitors. They've been in place for a long time. It's something we continue to look at. But I would say in the U.S., we're pretty sophisticated in terms of going through that analysis.

headline: Praxair Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Duffy Fischer from Barclays.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Duffy Fischer from Barclays.

headline: Praxair Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Question back on the CO2 business. So two, really. One, if you look out 3 to 5 years from now, from 10% today, how big could that business be in your relative portfolio? And then what are the real synergies as you build new business in other geographies?
componenttext: Question back on the CO2 business. So two, really. One, if you look out 3 to 5 years from now, from 10% today, how big could that business be in your relative portfolio? And then what are the real synergies as you build new business in other geographies? Is it a localized business like the rest of industrial gases? Or are there some real synergies between owning stuff in the U.S. and Europe, Latin America and Asia?

headline: Praxair Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would say it is very much a localized business. It is very dependent on getting high-quality sources and keeping them under contract. And if you're not able to do that, you're really not able to go at the CO2 business, so it's something we worked very h
componenttext: I would say it is very much a localized business. It is very dependent on getting high-quality sources and keeping them under contract. And if you're not able to do that, you're really not able to go at the CO2 business, so it's something we worked very hard to do. I would say the synergies would come more from just as you have more and more CO2 businesses, as you run around the world, more and more operations, more distribution, you just get better at how to run those plants. You get better at distribution. So that would be more so the synergy, I would say, from an operating efficiency standpoint. And then from a growth standpoint, I do believe that this has a lot of legs in terms of mid- to high single-digit growth going forward. So it will -- I don't know what the math is going to be, but it will increase from 10% of our sales today to something higher going forward. And if you -- the announcement that we made with MEGlobal where as Matt discussed, we're supplying oxygen and nitrogen to their greenfield ethylene glycol plant. We're also taking CO2 off of that plant, some 450 tons per day. And we're going to build a CO2 plant, and we're going to serve that local market. So that's 3 years out before that plant will start up. And so we have strong growth expectations for CO2 for some time to come.

headline: Praxair Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then another area, a little bit smaller for you guys. Political relations with Russia in the U.S. deteriorating quite a lot. Has that impacted your business there at all in the last couple months?
componenttext: Okay. And then another area, a little bit smaller for you guys. Political relations with Russia in the U.S. deteriorating quite a lot. Has that impacted your business there at all in the last couple months?

headline: Praxair Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: It has not because we stay below the radar screen. We don't supply gas from or some of those large companies that are very closely natural resource companies that are very closely aligned to the Kremlins. So we're kind of one level, one step removed from
componenttext: It has not because we stay below the radar screen. We don't supply gas from or some of those large companies that are very closely natural resource companies that are very closely aligned to the Kremlins. So we're kind of one level, one step removed from that. We're just an auction supplier to NTMK and word. And so I think it hasn't affected us nor would we expect to affect us.

headline: Praxair Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And that question is from PJ Juvekar of Citi. Our final question will come from Steve Berman of BofA Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: And that question is from PJ Juvekar of Citi. Our final question will come from Steve Berman of BofA Merrill Lynch.

headline: Praxair Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I did have a follow-up on the MEGlobal plant that you're building or that you're collaborating with. Matt, you indicated your ability to get that project had to do with your pipeline reliability, but yet you're building an ASU for that project. Can you ju
componenttext: I did have a follow-up on the MEGlobal plant that you're building or that you're collaborating with. Matt, you indicated your ability to get that project had to do with your pipeline reliability, but yet you're building an ASU for that project. Can you just comment a little bit about that? Is it that being tied into your pipeline, does that enable you to build a perhaps a smaller than necessary ASU? Or does it -- is it that the ASU has the backup from the pipeline and you can then have greater capacity in the pipeline? What do you see as the primary synergy here with the tying to the pipeline?

headline: Praxair Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think, Steve, when you look at a customer and it could be MEGlobal or any large petchem or processed chemical company, reliability is paramount, right? I mean, these operations run 24/7, and they're making these investments based on long-term view
componenttext: Yes, I think, Steve, when you look at a customer and it could be MEGlobal or any large petchem or processed chemical company, reliability is paramount, right? I mean, these operations run 24/7, and they're making these investments based on long-term view of their ability to produce their product and supply their product to get the return on those investments they're making. So it's absolutely critical that all suppliers, especially industrial gas suppliers, are able to keep them running and onstream. And so when they seek various bidders for their projects, they want to understand how you can ensure reliability to meet availability of 98, 99-plus percent on a 365-day basis. So having a pipeline complex, having the ability to store products, make products, buy product and channel it through a very large network of pipes really helps improve that reliability. So if one unit goes down, you have 30 other units that you can put into the system to help back it up. So yes, this asset will be interconnected, which gives a very strong reliability. And then obviously, it gives us some cost opportunities and efficiencies we can do along our whole system as well with that density. So this really plays into the density, and particularly on an on-site basis, but reliability and total cost of solution are the 2 most important things for somewhat of this type of nature. And that's what we're able to provide.

headline: Praxair Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then just the other side of this project with MEGlobal is the CO2 offtake. How do you influence the reliability of that stream? And perhaps, more importantly, the plant design to maximize the concentration of that stream?
componenttext: And then just the other side of this project with MEGlobal is the CO2 offtake. How do you influence the reliability of that stream? And perhaps, more importantly, the plant design to maximize the concentration of that stream?

headline: Praxair Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so we've been in the CO2 business since our inception. So we know how to take offtake crude CO2 in various offtake forms. This one happens to be a particularly cleaner one and more reliable based on the type of asset it's coming from. But this is som
componenttext: Yes, so we've been in the CO2 business since our inception. So we know how to take offtake crude CO2 in various offtake forms. This one happens to be a particularly cleaner one and more reliable based on the type of asset it's coming from. But this is something we do. We build, own and operate these plants ourselves, so no worry on that front. And as Steve mentioned, we have an existing large business in footprint and distribution network in CO2 already. So this adds to that ability to have strategic sources in the right locations to keep growing that business in these more resilient markets. So from that perspective, no concerns whatsoever. This is something that we do on an ongoing basis.

headline: Praxair Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you.
componenttext: Thank you.

headline: Praxair Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016

componenttext: Thank you again for participating in our third quarter earnings call. If you have any further questions, please feel free to reach out to me directly.
